A006002.name: a(n) = n*(n+1)^2/2.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{j=1..n} Sum_{i=1..j} (2*j - i + 1). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Nov 17 2014
a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} n*(n - i) + i. - _Bruno Berselli_, Jan 13 2016
a(n) = t(n, A000217(n)), where t(h,k) = A000217(h) + h*k. - _Bruno Berselli_, Feb 28 2017

A006003.name: a(n) = n*(n^2 + 1)/2.
formula: a(n) = binomial(n+2, 3) + binomial(n+1, 3) + binomial(n, 3). [corrected by _Michel Marcus_, Jan 22 2020]
Partial sums of A005448, centered triangular numbers: 3n(n-1)/2 + 1. - _Jonathan Vos Post_, Mar 16 2006
Binomial transform of [1, 4, 6, 3, 0, 0, 0, ...] = (1, 5, 15, 34, 65, ...). - _Gary W. Adamson_, Aug 10 2007
a(n) = -a(-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Dec 24 2011
a(n) = Sum_{k = 1..n} A(k-1, k-1-n) where A(i, j) = i^2 + i*j + j^2 + i + j + 1. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 02 2012
E.g.f.: (1/2)*(2*x + 3*x^2 + x^3)*exp(x). - _G. C. Greubel_, Dec 18 2015; corrected by _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Oct 12 2016
a(n) = T(n) + T(n-1) + T(n-2), where T means the tetrahedral-numbers, A000292. - _Heinz Dabrock_, Jun 03 2016
Sum_{n>=1} 1/a(n) = H(-i) + H(i) = 1.343731971048019675756781..., where H(k) is the harmonic number, i is the imaginary unit. (End)
Euler transform of length 3 sequence [5, 0, -1]. - _Michael Somos_, Dec 25 2016
a(n) = A037270(n)/n for n>0. - _Kritsada Moomuang_, Dec 15 2018
a(n) = A011863(n) - A011863(n-2). - _Bruce J. Nicholson_, Dec 22 2019
a(n) = C(n,1) + 3*C(n,2) + 3*C(n,3), where the coefficient of C(n,k) is the number of tetrahedron colorings using exactly k colors.

A006005.name: The odd prime numbers together with 1.
formula: a(n) = A175524(n) for n <= 30. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Jul 12 2011

A006007.name: 4-dimensional analog of centered polygonal numbers: a(n) = n(n+1)*(n^2+n+4)/12.

A006008.name: Number of inequivalent ways to color vertices of a regular tetrahedron using <= n colors.
formula: a(n) = (n^4 + 11*n^2)/12. (Replace all x_i's in the cycle index with n.)
Binomial transform of [1, 4, 6, 5, 2, 0, 0, 0, ...]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Apr 23 2008
a(n) = C(n,1) + 3C(n,2) + 3C(n,3) + 2C(n,4). Each term indicates the number of tetrahedra with exactly 1, 2, 3, or 4 colors. - _Robert A. Russell_, Dec 03 2014

A006009.name: Number of paraffins.
formula: a(n) = Sum(i=1, n, i*floor(i^2/2)). - _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Mar 10 2012

A006010.name: Number of paraffins (see Losanitsch reference for precise definition).
formula: If n is odd then a(n) = (1/8) * (n^4 + 2*n^3 + 2*n^2 + 2*n + 1) = Det(Transpose[M]*M) where M is the 2 X 3 matrix whose rows are [(n-1)/2, (n-1)/2], [(n-1)/2 + 1, 0] and [(n-1)/2 + 1, (n-1)/2 + 1]. If n is even then a(n) = (1/8) * (n^4 + 2*n^3 + 2*n^2) = Det(Transpose[M]*M) where M is the 2 X 3 matrix whose rows are [n/2, 0], [n/2, n/2] and [n/2 + 1, 0]. - _Gerald McGarvey_, Oct 30 2007

A006011.name: a(n) = n^2*(n^2 - 1)/4.
formula: Ceiling(sqrt(a(n)) + sqrt(a(n-1)))/2 = A000217(n). - _Richard R. Forberg_, Aug 14 2013
a(n) = Sum_{i=1..n-1} i*(i^2+n) for n > 1 (see Example section). - _Bruno Berselli_, Aug 29 2014

A006012.name: a(0) = 1, a(1) = 2, a(n) = 4*a(n-1) - 2*a(n-2), n >= 2.
formula: Binomial transform of A001333. E.g.f. exp(2x)cosh(x*sqrt(2)). - _Paul Barry_, May 08 2003
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..floor(n/2)} binomial(n, 2k)*2^(n-k) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(n, k)*2^(n-k/2)(1+(-1)^n)/2. - _Paul Barry_, Nov 22 2003
G.f.: G(0) where G(k)= 1 + 2*x/((1-2*x) - 2*x*(1-2*x)/(2*x + (1-2*x)*2/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 10 2012
G.f.: G(0)*(1-2*x)/2, where G(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - 2*x*(4*k+2-x)/( 2*x*(4*k+4-x) + 1/G(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 27 2014
a(-n) = a(n) / 2^n for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Aug 24 2014
a(n) = A265185(n) / 4, connecting this sequence to the simple Lie algebra B_4. - _Tom Copeland_, Dec 04 2015

A006013.name: a(n) = binomial(3*n+1,n)/(n+1).
formula: G.f. is square of g.f. for ternary trees, A001764 [Knuth, 2014]. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 09 2014
Convolution of A001764 with itself: 2*C(3*n + 2, n)/(3*n + 2), or C(3*n + 2, n+1)/(3*n + 2).
G.f.: A(x)/x with A(x)=x/(1-A(x))^2. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Dec 26 2010
a(n) is the top left term in M^n, where M is the infinite square production matrix:
a(n) is the sum of top row terms in Q^n, where Q is the infinite square production matrix as follows:
D-finite with recurrence: 2*(n+1)*(2n+1)*a(n) = 3*(3n-1)*(3n+1)*a(n-1). - _R. J. Mathar_, Dec 17 2011

A006014.name: a(n+1) = (n+1)*a(n)+ Sum a(k)*a(n-k).
formula: G.f. A(x) satisfies  A(x) = x * (1 + A(x) + A(x)^2 + x * A'(x)). - _Michael Somos_, Jul 24 2011

A006016.name: The nim value for the game of Sym with n tails and 1 head.

A006018.name: Periods for game of Third One Lucky.

A006019.name: Remoteness number of n in Simon Norton's game of Tribulations.

A006021.name: The game of contours.
formula: a(0) = 0, b(1) = 0, a(n) = mex({a(s) ^ b(t): s+t = n-1 and s>0} union {b(s) + b(t): s+t = n-1}), b(n) = mex({a(s) ^ b(t): s+t = n-1 and s>0}) with ^ denoting bitwise addition. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Dec 14 2016
a(n+8) = a(n) for n >= 6. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Dec 14 2016

A006022.name: Sprague-Grundy (or Nim) values for the game of Maundy cake on an n X 1 sheet.
formula: a(n) = n * Sum_{k=1..N} (1/(p1^m1*p2^m2*...*pk^mk)) * (pk^mk-1)/(pk-1) for n>=2, where pk is the k-th distinct prime factor of n, N is the number of distinct prime factors of n, and mk is the multiplicity of pk occurring in n. To prove this, expand the factors in Theorem 1 and use the geometrical series identity. - _Jonathan Blanchette_, Nov 01 2019

A006023.name: Number of unlabeled mating digraphs with n nodes.
formula: G.f. Sum_{n>=1} x^n * (Sum_{(j)} h((j)) * 2^Y((j)) * Product_{i=1..n} (1-x^i)^{j_i}) where the inner sum runs over all partitions (j) = j_1j_2...j_m of n = 1 * j_1 + 2 * j_2 + ... _ m * j_m, h((j)) = 1 / Product_{i=1..m} (j_i! * i^{j_i}), and  Y((j)) = Sum_{i=1..m} (i-1) * j_i + Sum_{i=1..m} i * j_i * (j_i - 1) + 2 * Sum_{1 <= i < k <= m} j_i * j_k * gcd(i, k). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Mar 06 2018

A006024.name: Number of labeled mating graphs with n nodes. Also called point-determining graphs.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} Stirling1(n, k)*2^binomial(k, 2). - R. C. Read (rcread(AT)math.uwaterloo.ca) and _Vladeta Jovovic_, Feb 10 2003

A006025.name: Number of labeled mating digraphs with n nodes.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} Stirling1(n, k)*2^(k^2-k). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Feb 11 2003

A006026.name: Number of column-convex polyominoes with perimeter n.
formula: The g.f. A(x) = x + x^2 + 3x^3 + ... satisfies A^3 - 3A^2 + (1+2x)A - x = 0. - _David Callan_, Nov 29 2007

A006027.name: Number of directed column-convex polyominoes with perimeter 2n+2.
formula: G.f. A(x) = a(1)x^2 + a(2)x^3 + a(3)x^4 + ... satisfies the functional equation A^3 + 2(x-1)A^2 + (2x-1)(x-1)A + (x^2)(x-1) = 0. - D. G. Rogers, May 22 2005

A006028.name: Weight distribution of [ 128,99,8 ] 4th order Reed-Muller code RM(4,7).

A006029.name: Numbers n such that n-th tetrahedral number n*(n+1)*(n+2)/6 is palindromic.

A006032.name: Numbers n such that (14^n - 1)/13 is prime.

A006033.name: Numbers n such that (15^n - 1)/14 is prime.

A006034.name: Numbers n such that (17^n-1)/16 is prime.

A006035.name: Numbers n such that (19^n-1)/18 is prime.

A006037.name: Weird numbers: abundant (A005101) but not pseudoperfect (A005835).

A006039.name: Primitive non-deficient numbers.
formula: Union of A000396 (perfect numbers) and A071395 (primitive abundant numbers). - _M. F. Hasler_, Jul 30 2016
Sum_{n>=1} 1/a(n) is in the interval (0.34842, 0.37937) (Lichtman, 2018). - _Amiram Eldar_, Jul 15 2020

A006040.name: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} (n!/(n-i)!)^2.
formula: The following formulas will need adjusting, since I have changed the offset. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 17 2013
a(n+1) = Nearest integer to BesselI(0, 2)*n!*n!, n >= 1.
a(n+1) = n!^2*Sum_{k = 0..n} 1/k!^2. BesselI(0, 2*sqrt(x))/(1-x) = Sum_{n>=0} a(n+1)*x^n/n!^2. - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Aug 30 2002

Recurrence: a(1) = 1, a(2) = 2, a(n+1) = (n^2+1)*a(n) - (n-1)^2*a(n-1), n >= 2. The sequence b(n) := (n-1)!^2 satisfies the same recurrence with the initial conditions b(1) = 1, b(2) = 1. It follows that a(n+1) = n!^2*(1 + 1/(1 - 1/(5 - 4/(10 - ...-(n-1)^2/(n^2+1))))). Hence BesselI(0,2) := sum {k = 0..inf} 1/k!^2 = 1 + 1/(1 - 1/(5 - 4/(10 - ...-(n-1)^2/(n^2+1 - ...)))). Cf. A073701. - _Peter Bala_, Jul 09 2008

A006043.name: A traffic light problem: expansion of 2/(1 - 3*x)^3.
formula: a(n) = (n+2)*(n+1)*3^n. - _Zerinvary Lajos_, Apr 25 2007, corrected by _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 14 2011

A006044.name: A traffic light problem.
formula: It seems that the g.f. is 6*x^4/(1-4*x)^4 (for the positive sequence), a(n)=6*A038846(n).. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Apr 29 2004

A006045.name: Sum of orders of all 2 X 2 matrices with entries mod n.

A006046.name: Total number of odd entries in first n rows of Pascal's triangle: a(0) = 0, a(1) = 1, a(2k) = 3*a(k), a(2k+1) = 2*a(k) + a(k+1). For n>0, a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n-1} 2^wt(i).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} 2^A000120(k). - _Paul Barry_, Jan 05 2005; simplified by _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 05 2014
For asymptotics see Stolarsky {1977). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 05 2014
a(n) = a(n-1) + A001316(n-1). a(2^n) = 3^n. - _Henry Bottomley_, Apr 05 2001
a(n) = n^(log_2(3))*G(log_2(n)) where G(x) is a function of period 1 defined by its Fourier series. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Aug 16 2002; formula modified by S. R. Finch, Dec 31 2007
G.f.: (x/(1-x))*Product_{k>=0} (1 + 2*x^2^k). - _Ralf Stephan_, Jun 01 2003; corrected by Herbert S. Wilf, Jun 16 2005

A006047.name: Number of entries in n-th row of Pascal's triangle not divisible by 3.
formula: Write n in base 3; if the representation contains r 1's and s 2's then a(n) = 3^s * 2^r. Also a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} (C(n, k)^2 mod 3). - Avi Peretz (njk(AT)netvision.net.il), Apr 21 2001
G.f. g(x) satisfies g(x) = (1 + 2*x + 3*x^2)*g(x^3). - _Robert Israel_, Oct 15 2015
a(n) = Product_{b_j != 0} a(b_j*3^j) where n = Sum_{j>=0} b_j*3^j is the ternary representation of n. (End)

A006048.name: Number of entries in first n rows of Pascal's triangle not divisible by 3.

A006049.name: Numbers n such that n and n+1 have the same number of distinct prime divisors.

A006050.name: Smallest number of additive persistence n.

A006051.name: Square hex numbers.
formula: G.f.: x * (1 - 26*x + x^2) / ((1 - x) * (1 - 194*x + x^2)). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation

A006052.name: Number of magic squares of order n composed of the numbers from 1 to n^2, counted up to rotations and reflections.

A006053.name: a(n) = a(n-1) + 2*a(n-2) - a(n-3).
formula: First differences of A028495. - _Floor van Lamoen_, Nov 02 2005
The previous formula connects the sequence a(n) with A214683, A215076, A215100, A120757. We may call a(n) the Ramanujan-type sequence number 2 for the argument 2*Pi/7. - _Roman Witula_, Aug 02 2012
a(n) = -A006054(1-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 30 2014

A006054.name: a(n) = 2*a(n-1) + a(n-2) - a(n-3), with a(0) = a(1) = 0, a(2) = 1.
formula: a(n+3) = sum(k=1..n, sum(j=0..k, binomial(j,n-3*k+2*j)*(-1)^(j-k)*binomial(k,j)*2^(-n+3*k-j))), a(0)=0, a(1)=0, a(2)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, May 05 2011
7*a(n) = (c(2)-c(4))*(1+c(1))^n + (c(4)-c(1))*(1+c(2))^n + (c(1)-c(2))*(1+c(4))^n, where c(j):=2*Cos(2Pi*j/7) - for the proof see Witula et al. papers. - _Roman Witula_, Aug 07 2012
a(n) = -A006053(1-n) for all n in Z. _Michael Somos_, Jun 25 2018

A006056.name: Number of topologies on n labeled points satisfying the T_4 axiom.
formula: E.g.f.: A4(X) = exp(Z4(X)-1) where Z4(x) denotes the e.g.f. for A006058. - Herman Jamke, Mar 02 2008

A006057.name: Number of topologies on n labeled points satisfying axioms T_0-T_4.
formula: E.g.f.: A04(x)=exp(Z04(x)-1) where Z04(x) denotes the E.g.f. for A006059. - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Mar 02 2008

A006058.name: Number of connected labeled T_4-topologies with n points.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n, k)*A000798(k) if n>=1.
E.g.f.: Z4(x) = A(x)*(exp(x)-1) + 1 where A(x) denotes the e.g.f. for A000798. (End)

A006059.name: Number of connected labeled T_0-T_4-topologies with n points.
formula: a(n) = n*A001035(n-1) for n>=1. - Herman Jamke (hermanjamke(AT)fastmail.fm), Mar 02 2008

A006061.name: Star numbers (A003154) that are squares.
formula: a(n) = denominator of kappa(sqrt(6)/A054320(n)) where kappa(x) is the sum of successive remainders by computing the Euclidean algorithm for (1, x). - _Thomas Baruchel_, Nov 29 2003

A006063.name: A card-arranging problem: values of n such that there exists a permutation p_1, ..., p_n of 1, ..., n such that i + p_i is a cube for every i.
formula: Conjecture: a(n) = n + 124 for n >= 173, i.e. there is such a permutation for every n >= 173.  Verified for 173 <= n <= 1000. - _Robert Israel_, Aug 28 2018

A006064.name: Smallest junction number with n generators.
formula: a(n) = the smallest m such that there are exactly n solutions to A062028(x)=m.

A006065.name: Maximal number of 4-tree rows in n-tree orchard problem.

A006066.name: Kobon triangles: maximal number of nonoverlapping triangles that can be formed from n lines drawn in the plane.
formula: An upper bound on this sequence is given by A032765.

For any odd n > 1, if n == 1 (mod 6), a(n) <= (n^2 - (2n + 2))/3; in other odd cases, a(n) <= (n^2 - 2n)/3. For any even n  > 0, if n == 4 (mod 6), a(n) <= (n^2 - (2n + 2))/3, otherwise a(n) <= (n^2 - 2n)/3. - _Sergey Pavlov_, Feb 11 2017

A006067.name: Number of ways to quarter an n X n chessboard.

A006068.name: a(n) is Gray-coded into n.
formula: a(n) = n XOR [n/2] XOR [n/4] XOR [n/8] ... XOR [n/2^m] where m = [log(n)/log(2)] (for n>0) and [x] is integer floor of x. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jun 04 2002
a(n) XOR [a(n)/2] = n. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jan 18 2012
a(n) = if n<2 then n else 2*m + (n mod 2 + m mod 2) mod 2, with m=a(floor(n/2)). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Aug 10 2010
a(n XOR m) = a(n) XOR a(m), where XOR is the bitwise exclusive-or operator, A003987. - _Peter Munn_, Dec 14 2019

A006069.name: Number of directed Hamiltonian cycles (or Gray codes) on n-cube with a marked starting node.

A006070.name: Number of Hamiltonian paths on n-cube which are strictly not cycles.

A006071.name: Maximal length of rook tour on an n X n board.
formula: The sequence is a hybrid of two sequences at the even and odd indices with linear recurrences individually, therefore a linear recurrence in total.
For even n the Gardner reference gives the formula a(n)=n(2n^2-5)/3+2, which is
with recurrence a(n)= 4 a(n-1) -6 a(n-2) +4 a(n-3) - a(n-4) and therefore with g.f. -2*(-2-11*x-4*x^2+x^3)/(x-1)^4 (offset 0) (see A152110).
For n odd the Gardner reference gives a(n)= n(2n^2-5)/3+1, which is
with the same recurrence and with g.f. -2*x*(-7-10*x+x^2)/(x-1)^4 (offset 0).
Since the first zero does not match the sequence and should be 1, we add 1 to the g.f.:
We "aerate" both sequences by insertion of zeros at each second position,
which implies x->x^2 in the generating functions,
The first of these is multiplied by x to shift it right by one place:
The sum of these two is
This is exactly the Plouffe g.f. if the offset were 0.

A006072.name: Numbers with mirror symmetry about middle.
formula: a(n) = digit-wise application of A000578 to A118594(n). - _M. F. Hasler_, May 08 2013

A006073.name: Numbers n such that n, n+1 and n+2 all have same number of distinct prime divisors.

A006074.name: Number of polyaboloes (or polytans): number of different shapes that can be formed with n congruent isosceles right triangles, identifying mirror images.

A006075.name: Minimal number of knights needed to cover an n X n board.

A006076.name: Sequence A006075 gives minimal number of knights needed to cover an n X n board. This sequence gives number of inequivalent solutions using A006075(n) knights.

A006078.name: Number of triangulated (n+2)-gons rooted at an exterior edge.

A006079.name: Number of asymmetric planted projective plane trees with n+1 nodes; bracelets (reversible necklaces) with n black beads and n-1 white beads.
formula: Let c(x) = (1-sqrt(1-4*x))/(2*x) = g.f. for Catalan numbers (A000108), let d(x) = x/(1-x-x^2*c(x^2)) = g.f. for A001405. Then g.f. for the asymmetric planted projective plane trees sequence is (x*c(x)-d(x))/2 (the initial terms from this version are slightly different).

A006080.name: Number of rooted projective plane trees with n nodes.

A006081.name: Number of line-rooted projective plane trees with n nodes.

A006082.name: Number of labeled projective plane trees (or "flat" trees) with n nodes.
formula: a(n) = A006080(n) - A006081(n) + A126120(n-2). [Stockmeyer] [Corrected by _Andrey Zabolotskiy_, Apr 06 2021]

A006085.name: Continued fraction for e/4.
formula: First seven terms are 0, 1, 2, 8, 3, 1, 1; then a(8k)=1, a(8k+1)=k, a(8k+2)=7, a(8k+3)=1, a(8k+4)=k, a(8k+5)=2, a(8k+6)=1, a(8k+7)=1. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 08 2003

A006086.name: Unitary harmonic numbers (those for which the unitary harmonic mean is an integer).
formula: If m is a term and omega(m) = A001221(m) = k, then m < 2^(k*2^k) (Goto, 2007). - _Amiram Eldar_, Jun 06 2020

A006087.name: Unitary harmonic means H(n) of the unitary harmonic numbers (A006086).

A006088.name: a(n) = (2^n + 2) a(n-1) (kissing number of Barnes-Wall lattice in dimension 2^n).
formula: a(n) ~ c * 2^(n*(n+1)/2), where c = A081845. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Dec 31 2015

A006091.name: a(n) = n^n - n + 1.
formula: E.g.f.: 1/(1 + LambertW(-x)) + exp(x)*(1 - x) - 2. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Oct 30 2017

A006092.name: Numbers beginning with letter 't' when spelled out in English.
formula: Let g_k(x) = (x^(2k) - x^(4k) + x^(10k) - x^(11k) + x^(12k) - x^(14k) + x^(20k) - x^(40k) + x^(200k) - x^(400k))/(1-x). Then the g.f. of the characteristic function of this sequence is sum(j>=0, g_{1000^j}(x).

A006093.name: a(n) = prime(n) - 1.
formula: a(n) = (p-1)! mod p where p is the n-th prime, by Wilson's theorem. - _Jonathan Sondow_, Jul 13 2010

A006095.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [n,2] for q=2.
formula: Row sums of triangle A130324. - _Gary W. Adamson_, May 24 2007
a(n) = stirling2(n+1,3) + stirling2(n+1,4). - _Zerinvary Lajos_, Oct 04 2007, corrected by _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 19 2011
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-2} 2^k*C(2*n-k-2, k), n >= 2. - _Johannes W. Meijer_, Aug 19 2013

A006096.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,3 ] for q=2.
formula: (With a different offset) a(n)=(-1+7*2^n-14*4^n+8*8^n)/21. - _James R. Buddenhagen_, Dec 14 2003

A006097.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,4 ] for q=2.

A006098.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ 2n,n ] for q=2.
formula: a(n) ~ c * 2^(n^2), where c = A065446. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Sep 22 2016

A006099.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n, n/2 ] for q=2.

A006100.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,2 ] for q=3.

A006101.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,3 ] for q=3.
formula: G.f.: z^3/((1-z)(1-3z)(1-9z)(1-27z)). _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation

A006102.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,4 ] for q=3.

A006104.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,n/2 ] for q=3.

A006105.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,2 ] for q=4.
formula: G.f.: x^2/((1-x)*(1-4*x)*(1-16*x)). [Multiplied by x^2 to match offset by _R. J. Mathar_, Mar 11 2009]

A006106.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,3 ] for q = 4.
formula: G.f.: x^3/((1-x)*(1-4*x)*(1-16*x)*(1-64*x)). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation
a(n) = Product_{i=1..3} (4^(n-i+1)-1)/(4^i-1), by definition. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 07 2016

A006107.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,4 ] for q = 4.
formula: a(n) = Product_{i=1..4} (4^(n-i+1)-1)/(4^i-1), by definition. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 07 2016

A006109.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,n/2 ] for q=4.

A006110.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,5 ] for q = 2.
formula: a(n) = Product_{i=1..5} (2^(n-i+1)-1)/(2^i-1), by definition. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 06 2016

A006111.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,2 ] for q=5.

A006112.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,3 ] for q = 5.
formula: a(n) = Product_{i=1..3} (5^(n-i+1)-1)/(5^i-1), by definition. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 07 2016

A006113.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,4 ] for q = 5.
formula: a(n) = Product_{i=1..4} (5^(n-i+1)-1)/(5^i-1), by definition. - _Vincenzo Librandi_, Aug 06 2016

A006115.name: Gaussian binomial coefficient [ n,n/2 ] for q=5.

A006116.name: Sum of Gaussian binomial coefficients [n,k] for q=2 and k=0..n.
formula: O.g.f.: A(x) = Sum_{n>=0} x^n / Product_{k=0..n} (1 - 2^k*x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Dec 06 2007
Coefficients of the square of the q-exponential of x evaluated at q=2, where the q-exponential of x = Sum_{n>=0} x^n/F(n) and F(n) = Product{i=1..n} (q^i-1)/(q-1) is the q-factorial of n.
G.f.: (Sum_{k=0..n} x^n/F(n))^2 = Sum_{k=0..n} a(n)*x^n/F(n) where F(n) = A005329(n) = Product{i=1..n} (2^i - 1).
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} F(n)/(F(k)*F(n-k)) where F(n)=A005329(n) is the 2-factorial of n.
G.f.: 1 + x*(G(0) - 1)/(x-1) where G(k) = 1 - 1/(1-2^k*x)/(1-x/(x-1/G(k+1) )); (recursively defined continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 16 2013
a(n) = 2*a(n-1) + (2^(n-1)-1)*a(n-2). [Hitzemann and Hochstattler]. - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 21 2013

a(n) ~ c * 2^(n^2/4), where c = EllipticTheta[3,0,1/2] / QPochhammer[1/2,1/2] = 7.3719688014613... if n is even and c = EllipticTheta[2,0,1/2] / QPochhammer[1/2,1/2] = 7.3719494907662... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 21 2013

A006117.name: Sum of Gaussian binomial coefficients [ n,k ] for q=3.
formula: O.g.f.: A(x) = Sum_{n>=0} x^n / Product_{k=0..n} (1 - 3^k*x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Dec 06 2007
a(n) = 2*a(n-1)+(3^(n-1)-1)*a(n-2), n>1. [Hitzemann and Hochstattler] - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 21 2013

a(n) ~ c * 3^(n^2/4), where c = EllipticTheta[3,0,1/3] / QPochhammer[1/3,1/3] = 3.019783845699... if n is even and c = EllipticTheta[2,0,1/3]/QPochhammer[1/3,1/3] = 3.018269046371... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 21 2013
0 = a(n)*(2*a(n+1) + 2*a(n+2) - a(n+3)) + a(n+1)*(-6*a(n+1) + 3*a(n+2)) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 25 2014

A006118.name: Sum of Gaussian binomial coefficients [ n,k ] for q=4.
formula: a(n) = 2*a(n-1)+(4^(n-1)-1)*a(n-2), n>1. [Hitzemann and Hochstattler]. - _R. J. Mathar_, Aug 21 2013

a(n) ~ c * 4^(n^2/4), where c = EllipticTheta[3,0,1/4]/QPochhammer[1/4,1/4] = 2.189888057761... if n is even and c = EllipticTheta[2,0,1/4]/QPochhammer[1/4,1/4] = 2.182810929357... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 21 2013

A006119.name: Sum of Gaussian binomial coefficients [ n,k ] for q=5.
formula: a(n) ~ c * 5^(n^2/4), where c = EllipticTheta[3,0,1/5]/QPochhammer[1/5,1/5] = 1.845509008203... if n is even and c = EllipticTheta[2,0,1/5]/QPochhammer[1/5,1/5] = 1.829548121746... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 21 2013

A006120.name: Sum of Gaussian binomial coefficients [ n,k ] for q=6.
formula: a(n) ~ c * 6^(n^2/4), where c = EllipticTheta[3,0,1/6]/QPochhammer[1/6,1/6] = 1.656816524577... if n is even and c = EllipticTheta[2,0,1/6]/QPochhammer[1/6,1/6] = 1.630173070572... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 21 2013

A006121.name: Sum of Gaussian binomial coefficients [ n,k ] for q=7.
formula: a(n) ~ c * 7^(n^2/4), where c = EllipticTheta[3,0,1/7]/QPochhammer[1/7,1/7] = 1.537469386940... if n is even and c = EllipticTheta[2,0,1/7]/QPochhammer[1/7,1/7] = 1.499386995418... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 21 2013

A006122.name: Sum of Gaussian binomial coefficients [ n,k ] for q=8.
formula: a(n) ~ c * 8^(n^2/4), where c = EllipticTheta[3,0,1/8]/QPochhammer[1/8,1/8] = 1.455061175158... if n is even and c = EllipticTheta[2,0,1/8]/QPochhammer[1/8,1/8] = 1.405381182498... if n is odd. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Aug 21 2013

A006125.name: a(n) = 2^(n*(n-1)/2).
formula: Sequence is given by the Hankel transform of A001003 (Schroeder's numbers)= 1, 1, 3, 11, 45, 197, 903, ...; example: det([1, 1, 3, 11; 1, 3, 11, 45; 3, 11, 45, 197; 11, 45, 197, 903]) = 2^6 = 64. - _Philippe Deléham_, Mar 02 2004
G.f. satisfies: A(x) = 1 + x*A(2x). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Dec 04 2009
G.f.: G(0)/x -1/x, where G(k) = 1 + 2^(k-1)*x/(1 - 1/(1 + 1/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 26 2013
E.g.f. satisfies A'(x) = A(2x). - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Sep 07 2013

A006126.name: Number of hierarchical models on n labeled factors or variables with linear terms forced. Also number of antichain covers of a labeled n-set.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k = 1..C(n, floor(n/2))} b(k, n), where b(k, n) is the number of k-antichain covers of a labeled n-set.
Inverse binomial transform of A000372. - _Gus Wiseman_, Feb 24 2019

A006127.name: a(n) = 2^n + n.
formula: Row sums of triangle A135227. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 23 2007
Partial sums of A094373. G.f.: (1-x-x^2)/((1-x)^2(1-2x)). - _Paul Barry_, Aug 05 2004
Binomial transform of [1,2,1,1,1,1,1,...]. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Nov 29 2006

A006128.name: Total number of parts in all partitions of n. Also, sum of largest parts of all partitions of n.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{m=1..n} of the number of divisors of m * number of partitions of n-m.
Note that the formula for the above comment is a(n) = Sum_{m=1..n} d(m)*p(n-m) = Sum_{m=1..n} A000005(m)*A000041(n-m), if n >= 1. - _Omar E. Pol_, Jan 21 2013
Erdős and Lehner show that if u(n) denotes the average largest part in a partition of n, then u(n) ~ constant*sqrt(n)*log n.
a(n) = A066897(n) + A066898(n), n>0. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Mar 09 2012
a(n) = O(sqrt(n)*log(n)*p(n)), where p(n) is the partition function A000041(n). - _Peter Bala_, Dec 23 2013

Asymptotics (Luthra, 1957): a(n) = p(n) * (C*N^(1/2) + C^2/2) * (log(C*N^(1/2)) + gamma) + (1+C^2)/4 + O(N^(-1/2)*log(N)), where N = n - 1/24, C = sqrt(6)/Pi, gamma is the Euler-Mascheroni constant A001620 and p(n) is the partition function A000041(n).

The formula a(n) = p(n) * (sqrt(3*n/(2*Pi)) * (log(n) + 2*gamma - log(Pi/6)) + O(log(n)^3)) in the abstract of the article by Kessler and Livingston (cited also in the book by Sandor, p. 495) is incorrect!
Right is: a(n) = p(n) * (sqrt(3*n/2)/Pi * (log(n) + 2*gamma - log(Pi^2/6)) + O(log(n)^3))
G.f.: (log(1-x) + psi_x(1))/(log(x) * (x)_inf), where psi_q(z) is the q-digamma function, and (q)_inf is the q-Pochhammer symbol (the Euler function). - _Vladimir Reshetnikov_, Nov 17 2016

A006129.name: a(0), a(1), a(2), ... satisfy Sum_{k=0..n} a(k)*binomial(n,k) = 2^binomial(n,2), for n >= 0.
formula: E.g.f.: A(x)/exp(x) where A(x) = Sum_{n>=0} 2^C(n,2) x^n/n!. - _Geoffrey Critzer_, Oct 21 2011

A006130.name: a(n) = a(n-1) + 3*a(n-2) for n > 1, a(0) = a(1) = 1.
formula: O.g.f.: 1/(1 - x - 3*x^2). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation.
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..ceiling(n/2)} 3^k*C(n-k, k)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, _Philippe Deléham_, Mar 07 2004
The i-th term of the sequence is the (1, 2) entry in the i-th power of the 2 X 2 matrix M = ((-1, 1), (1, 2)). - _Simone Severini_, Oct 15 2005
a(n) = lower right term in the 2 X 2 matrix [0,3; 1,1]^n. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Mar 02 2008
a(n) = Product_{k = 1..floor((n - 1)/2)} (1 + 12*cos(k*Pi/n)^2). - _Roger L. Bagula_ and _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 21 2008
Limiting ratio = (1 + sqrt(13))/2 = 2.30277563.. = A098316 - 1. - _Roger L. Bagula_ and _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 21 2008
G.f.: G(0)/(2-x), where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - x*(13*k - 1)/(x*(13*k + 12) - 2/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 18 2013
G.f.: Q(0)/2 , where Q(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(4*k+1 + 3*x)/( x*(4*k+3 + 3*x) + 1/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Sep 08 2013
a(n) = ( Sum_{1 <= k <= n+1, k odd} C(n+1,k)*13^((k-1)/2) )/2^n. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Feb 05 2014
E.g.f.: (1/(a - b))*(a*exp(a*x) - b*exp(b*x)), where 2*a = 1 + sqrt(13) and 2*b = 1 - sqrt(13). - _G. C. Greubel_, Aug 30 2015
a(n) = ((i*sqrt(3))^n)*S(n, (-i/sqrt(3))), with the imaginary unit i and the Chebyshev S polynomials (coefficients in A049130). - _Wolfdieter Lang_, Feb 18 2018
a(n) = hypergeom([(1-n)/2, -n/2], [-n], -12) for n >= 1. - _Peter Luschny_, Feb 18 2018
a(n) = 3 * (-3)^n * a(-2-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 04 2018
a(n) = ( sqrt(3) )^n * Fibonacci(n+1, 1/sqrt(3)). - _G. C. Greubel_, Dec 26 2019
a(n) = numerator of the continued fraction 1 + 3/(1 + 3/(1 + 3/ ... + 3/1)) with exactly n 1's, for n>0. - _Greg Dresden_ and _Alexander Mark_, Aug 16 2020

A006131.name: a(n) = a(n-1) + 4*a(n-2), a(0) = a(1) = 1.
formula: Limiting ratio a(n+1)/a(n) is (1 + sqrt(17))/2 = 2.561552812... - _Roger L. Bagula_, Nov 21 2008

The fraction b(n) = a(n)/2^n satisfies b(n) = 1/2 b(n-1) + b(n-2); g.f. 1/(1-x/2-x^2); b(n) = (( (1+sqrt(17))/4 )^(n+1) - ( (1-sqrt(17))/4 )^(n+1))*2/sqrt(17). - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Nov 30 2009
G.f.: G(0)/(2-x), where G(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(17*k-1)/(x*(17*k+16) - 2/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 20 2013
G.f.: Q(0)/2 , where Q(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(4*k+1 + 4*x)/( x*(4*k+3 + 4*x) + 1/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Sep 09 2013
G.f.: Q(0)/2 , where Q(k) = 1 + 1/(1 - x*(k+1 + 4*x)/( x*(k+3/2 + 4*x ) + 1/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Sep 14 2013
a(n) = (Sum_{1<=k<=n+1, k odd} C(n+1,k)*17^((k-1)/2))/2^n. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, Feb 05 2014

A006132.name: Related to representations as sums of Fibonacci numbers.

A006133.name: Related to representations as sums of Fibonacci numbers.

A006134.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(2*k,k).
formula: a(n) = Sum[((2k)!/(k!)^2),{k,0,n}]. a(n) = A066796(n) + 1, n>0. - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Jul 05 2006
a(n) = Sum_{ k=0..n } b(k)*binomial(n+k,k), where b(k)=0 for n-k == 2 (mod 3), b(k)=1 for n-k == 0 or 1 (mod 6), and b(k)=-1 for n-k== 3 or 4 (mod 6).
a(n) = Sum_{ k=0..n-1 } c(k)*binomial(2n,k) + binomial(2n,n), where c(k)=0 for n-k == 0 (mod 3), c(k)=1 for n-k== 1 (mod 3), and c(k)=-1 for n-k==2 (mod 3). (End)
G.f.: G(0)/2/(1-x), where G(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - 2*x*(2*k+1)/(2*x*(2*k+1) + (k+1)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 24 2013
G.f.: G(0)/(1-x), where G(k)= 1 + 4*x*(4*k+1)/( (4*k+2) - x*(4*k+2)*(4*k+3)/(x*(4*k+3) + (k+1)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 26 2013

A006135.name: T(n+2,2) from table A045912 of characteristic polynomial of negative Pascal matrix.

A006136.name: T(n+3,3) from table A045912 of characteristic polynomial of negative Pascal matrix.

A006138.name: a(n) = a(n-1) + 3*a(n-2).
formula: a(n) = (i*sqrt(3))^(n-1)*(i*sqrt(3)*ChebyshevU(n, 1/(2*i*sqrt(3))) + ChebyshevU(n-1, 1/(2*i*sqrt(3)))), where i=sqrt(-1). - _G. C. Greubel_, Nov 19 2019

A006139.name: n*a(n) = 2*(2*n-1)*a(n-1) + 4*(n-1)*a(n-2) with a(0) = 1.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} C(2*k, k)*C(k, n-k). - Detlef Pauly (dettodet(AT)yahoo.de), Nov 08 2001
G.f.: 1/(1-4x-4x^2)^(1/2); also, a(n) is the central coefficient of (1+2x+2x^2)^n. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jun 01 2003
Inverse binomial transform of central Delannoy numbers A001850. - _David Callan_, Mar 14 2004
It appears that Pi/2 = Sum_{n >= 1} (-1)^(n-1)*4^n/(n*a(n-1)*a(n)). - _Peter Bala_, Feb 20 2017
G.f.: G(x) = (1/(2*Pi))*Integral_{y=0..2*Pi} 1/(1-x*(4*(sin(y)-cos(y))*sin(y)))*dy, also satisfies: (2+4*x)*G(x)-(1-4*x-4*x^2)*G'(x)=0. - _Bradley Klee_, Jul 19 2018

A006141.name: Number of integer partitions of n whose smallest part is equal to the number of parts.
formula: Plouffe in his 1992 dissertation conjectured that this has g.f. = (1+z+z**4+2*z**5-z**3-z**8+3*z**10-z**7+z**9)/(1+z-z**4-2*z**3-z**8+z**10), but _Michael Somos_ pointed out on Jan 22 2008 that this is false.
Expansion of ( f(-x^2, -x^3) - f(-x, -x^4) ) / f(-x) in powers of x where f(, ) is Ramanujan's general theta function. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 22 2007

A006142.name: Number of certain self-avoiding walks with n steps on square lattice (see reference for precise definition).

A006143.name: Number of certain self-avoiding walks with n steps on square lattice (see reference for precise definition).

A006144.name: Number of certain self-avoiding walks with n steps on square lattice (see reference for precise definition).

A006145.name: Ruth-Aaron numbers (1): sum of prime divisors of n = sum of prime divisors of n+1.

A006146.name: Sums of prime divisors of Ruth-Aaron numbers (A006145).

A006148.name: Number of 4 X n binary matrices up to row and column permutations.

A006149.name: Number of Dyck paths.
formula: a(n) = Det[Table[binomial[i+2, j-i+3], {i, 1, n}, {j, 1, n}]]. - _David Callan_, Jul 20 2005

A006150.name: Number of Dyck paths.
formula: a(n) = Det[Table[binomial[i+3, j-i+4], {i, 1, n}, {j, 1, n}]]. - _David Callan_, Jul 20 2005

A006152.name: Exponential generating function x*exp(x/(1-x)).
formula: D-finite with recurrence a(n) = 2*(n-1)*a(n-1)-(n^2-5*n+5)*a(n-2)-(n-4)*(n-2)*a(n-3). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 05 2012

A006153.name: E.g.f.: 1/(1-x*exp(x)).
formula: For n>=1, a(n-1) = b(n) where b(1)=1 and b(n) = Sum_{i=1..n-1} i*binomial(n-1, i)*b(i). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Nov 13 2004
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n}A199673(n,k) = Sum_{k=1..n}n! k^(n-k)/(n-k)!. - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Nov 15 2011
E.g.f. for a(n), n>=1: x*e^x/(1-x*e^x). - _Dennis P. Walsh_, Nov 15 2011
O.g.f.: Sum_{n>=0} n! * x^n / (1 - n*x)^(n+1). - _Paul D. Hanna_, May 22 2018
a(0) = 1; a(n) = n * Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n-1,k) * a(k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jul 12 2020

A006154.name: Number of labeled ordered partitions of an n-set into odd parts.
formula: With alternating signs, e.g.f.: 1/(1+sinh(x)). - _Ralf Stephan_, Apr 29 2004
a(0) = a(1) = 1, a(n) = Sum_{k=1..ceiling(n/2)} C(n,2*k-1)*a(n-2*k+1). - _Ralf Stephan_, Apr 29 2004
From A. N. W. Hone (A.N.W.Hone(AT)kent.ac.uk), Feb 22 2007: (Start)

This formula can be proved using the techniques in the article by Philippe Flajolet, Symbolic Enumerative Combinatorics and Complex Asymptotic Analysis, Algorithms Seminar 2000-2001, F. Chyzak (ed.), INRIA, (2002), pp. 161-170 [see Theorem 5 and Table 2, noting that 1/(1-sinh(x)) just has a simple pole at x=log(1+sqrt(2)]. (End)
a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} Sum_{i=0..k} (-1)^i*(k-2*i)^n*binomial(k,i)/2^k, n > 0, a(0)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, May 28 2011
Row sums (apart from a(0)) of A196776. - _Peter Bala_, Oct 06 2011
Row sums of A193474. - _Peter Luschny_, Oct 07 2011
a(n) = D^n(1/(1-x)) evaluated at x = 0, where D is the operator sqrt(1+x^2)*d/dx. Cf. A003724 and A000111. - _Peter Bala_, Dec 06 2011
Let E(x) be the e.g.f., then
E.g.f. 1/(1 - x*G(0)) where G(k) = 1 - x^2/( (2*k+1)*(2*k+3) - 2*k+1)*(2*k+3)^2/(2*k+3 - (2*k+2)/G(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 01 2012

A006155.name: Expansion of e.g.f. 1/(2-x-e^x).
formula: a(n) ~ n! / ((1+c) * (2-c)^(n+1)), where c = A226571 = LambertW(exp(2)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jun 06 2019
a(0) = 1; a(n) = n * a(n-1) + Sum_{k=0..n-1} binomial(n,k) * a(k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Jul 02 2020

A006156.name: Number of ternary squarefree words of length n.
formula: a(n) >= 2^(n/17), see Zeilberger. Let L = lim a(n)^(1/n); then L exists and Grimm proves 1.109999 < L < 1.317278. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Nov 29 2013
L exists since a(n) is submultiplicative; 1.3017597 < L < 1.3017619 (Shur 2012); the gap between the bounds can be made less than any given constant. - _Arseny Shur_, Apr 22 2015

A006157.name: a(n+1) = (n-1)*a(n) + n*n!.
formula: E.g.f.: x^2*(3-x)/(6*(1-x)^2). - _Emeric Deutsch_ and _Ira M. Gessel_, Sep 07 2004

A006165.name: a(1) = a(2) = 1; thereafter a(2n+1) = a(n+1) + a(n), a(2n) = 2a(n).
formula: For n>=2, if a(n)>=A006257(n), i.e., if msb(n)>n-a(n)/2, then a(n+1)=a(n)+1, otherwise a(n+1)=a(n). - _Henry Bottomley_, Jan 21 2002

A006167.name: Number of factorization patterns of polynomials of degree n over F_2.
formula: Euler transform of sequence b(n) = sum_{d|n, A001037(d)>=n/d} 1. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 19 2006

A006168.name: Number of factorization patterns of polynomials of degree n over F_3.
formula: Euler transform of sequence b(n) = sum_{d|n, A027376(d)>=n/d} 1. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 19 2006

A006169.name: Number of factorization patterns of polynomials of degree n over F_4.
formula: Euler transform of sequence b(n) = sum_{d|n, A027377(d)>=n/d} 1. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 19 2006

A006170.name: Number of factorization patterns of polynomials of degree n over F_5.
formula: Euler transform of sequence b(n) = sum_{d|n, A001692(d)>=n/d} 1. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 19 2006

A006171.name: Number of factorization patterns of polynomials of degree n over integers.
formula: Euler transform of tau(n), tau(n) = the number of divisors of n, cf. A000005.

a(n) = Sum_{<b(i)^k(i)> partition of n} product p(k(i)), where p(n) is the partition function A000041. E.g., for the partition [4,2^3,1^4], the product is p(1)*p(3)*p(4) = 1*3*5 = 15. - _Franklin T. Adams-Watters_, Jun 19 2006
G.f.: A(x) = exp( Sum_{n>=1} sigma(n)*x^n/(1-x^n)/n ). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Mar 28 2009
G.f.: A(x) = exp( Sum_{n>=1} A060640(n)*x^n/n ), where A060640(n) = Sum_{d|n} d*sigma(n/d). (End)
G.f.: 1/Product_{n>=1} E(q^n) where E(q) = Product_{n>=1} (1-q^n). - _Joerg Arndt_, Feb 27 2014

a(n) ~ exp(Pi*sqrt(n/(3*log(n))) * (log(n) - log(log(n))/2 + gamma + 6*Zeta'(2)/Pi^2 + log(2/Pi) + log(3)/2)) * Pi^(1/4) * (log(n))^(1/8) / (2^(3/4) * 3^(1/8) * n^(5/8)), where gamma is the Euler-Mascheroni constant (A001620) and Zeta'(2) = -0.9375482543158437537... (see A073002) [user Lucia, MathOverflow, 2014]. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jan 05 2017

A006173.name: Witt vector *2!.
formula: Inverse Somos transform of A000108 shifted left. - _Wouter Meeussen_, Aug 20 2002
Witt transform of A060165. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jan 15 2017

A006177.name: Witt vector *2!/2!.
formula: Inverse Somos transform of A000108. - _Wouter Meeussen_, Aug 20 2002

A006181.name: Maximal partial Steiner triple systems of order n.

A006182.name: Deficiencies of partial Steiner triple systems of order n.

A006183.name: a(n) = (n+1)*a(n-1) + (2-n)*a(n-2).
formula: G.f.: 2*Sum_{k>=0} k!*(x/(1-x))^k  - 1 = Q(0) -1, where Q(k)= 1 + 1/(1 - x*(k+1)/(x*(k+1) + (1-x)/Q(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Aug 08 2013

A006184.name: Number of cycles in the complement of a path.
formula: a(n) = (1/2)*Sum_{k=3..n} Sum_{i=1..k} Sum_{j=0..k-i} (-1)^(k-i)*(i-1)!*2^j*binomial(n+i-k, i)*binomial(i, j)*binomial(k-i-1, k-i-j). - _Andrew Howroyd_, Apr 21 2018

A006185.name: Number of pair-coverings with largest block size 3.
formula: a(n) = n*(n-1)/6 if n=1 or 3 (mod 6), a(n) = n*(n+1)/6 if n = 0 or 2 (mod 6), a(n) = (n^2+n+4)/6 if n = 4 (mod 6), and a(n) = (n^2-n+16)/6 if n = 5 (mod 6). [From Grannell et al.] - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jan 17 2017

A006186.name: Number of pair-coverings with largest block size 4.

A006187.name: Number of pair-coverings with largest block size 5.

A006189.name: Number of self-avoiding walks of any length from NW to SW corners of a grid or lattice with n rows and 3 columns.
formula: a(n) = 4*a(n-1) - 3*a(n-2) + 2*a(n-3) + a(n-4) for n > 3. - _Giovanni Resta_, Mar 13 2013
a(n) = (1/2)*( ChebyshevU(n, 1/2) - ChebyshevU(n-1, 1/2) + i^n*( ChebyshevU(n, -3*i/2) + i*ChebyshevU(n-1, -3*i/2) ) ). - _G. C. Greubel_, May 24 2021

A006190.name: a(n) = 3*a(n-1) + a(n-2), with a(0)=0, a(1)=1.
formula: a(n) = F(n, 3), the n-th Fibonacci polynomial evaluated at x=3.
Let M = {{0, 1}, {1, 3}}, v[1] = {0, 1}, v[n] = M.v[n - 1]; then a(n) = Abs[v[n][[1]]]. - _Roger L. Bagula_, May 29 2005 [Or a(n) = [M^(n+1)]_{1,1}. - _L. Edson Jeffery_, Aug 27 2013
a(n) = (ap^n - am^n)/(ap - am), with ap = (3 + sqrt(13))/2, am = (3 - sqrt(13))/2.

Let C = (3 + sqrt(13))/2 = exp arcsinh(3/2) = 3.3027756377... Then C^n, n > 0 = a(n)*(1/C) + a(n+1). Let X = the 2 X 2 matrix [0, 1; 1, 3]. Then X^n = [a(n-1), a(n); a(n), a(n+1)]. - _Gary W. Adamson_, Dec 21 2007
a(n) = ((3 + sqrt(13))^n - (3 - sqrt(13))^n)/(2^n*sqrt(13)). - Al Hakanson (hawkuu(AT)gmail.com), Jan 12 2009
(1) Expression a(n+1) via a(n): a(n+1) = (3*a(n) + sqrt(13*a^2(n) + 4*(-1)^n)/2;
(7) 3*Sum_{k=2..n+1} a(k)*a(k-1) is equal to a(n+1)^2 if n odd, and is equal to a(n+1)^2 - 1 if n is even;
The same formula holds for Fibonacci numbers and Pell numbers.  (End)

A006191.name: Number of paths on square lattice.
formula: a(n) = 1 + Sum_{k=1..n-1} A006189(k). - _Sean A. Irvine_, Jan 20 2017

A006192.name: Number of nonintersecting (or self-avoiding) rook paths joining opposite corners of 3 X n board.

A006193.name: Number of n-node animals on cubic lattice.

A006194.name: Number of n-node animals on f.c.c. lattice (invert A007199).

A006196.name: Number of leftist trees with n leaves.
formula: G.f. satisfies A(x) = x+A(x*A(x)). - P. Nogueira, Oct 24 2003
Series reversion of g.f. A(x) is -A(-x). - _Michael Somos_, Jul 13 2003
a(n)=T(n,1),a(0)=0, T(n,m)=sum(j=0..m-1, binomial(m,j)* sum(k=0..floor((n+j)/2)-m, T(n-k-m,k+m-j)*T(k+m-j,m-j))), n>m, T(n,n)=1. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, May 04 2012

A006198.name: Number of partitions into pairs.
formula: G.f.: T(0) - 1, where T(k) = 1 - (k+1)*x/( (k+1)*x - (1+x)^2/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 03 2013
a(-n) = -a(n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Jan 27 2014
E.g.f. (for offset 0): ((2 - 2*x - (1 - 2*x)^(1/2)) / (1-2*x)^(3/2)) * exp((1-2*x)^(1/2) - 1) (formula due to B. Salvy, see Plouffe link). - _Gheorghe Coserea_, Aug 05 2015

A006199.name: Bessel polynomial {y_n}'(-1).
formula: a(n) = 2*n*(1/2)_{n} * (-2)^(n-1) * hyergeometric1f1(1-n; -2*n; -2), where (a)_{n} is the Pochhammer symbol.
G.f.: (x/(1-x)^3)*hypergeometric2f0(2,3/2; - ; -2*x/(1-x)^2), for offset 0. - _G. C. Greubel_, Aug 16 2017

A006201.name: Number of colorings of labeled graphs on n nodes using exactly 3 colors, divided by 48.

A006202.name: Number of colorings of labeled graphs on n nodes using exactly 4 colors, divided by 4!*2^6.

A006203.name: Discriminants of imaginary quadratic fields with class number 3 (negated).

A006204.name: Number of starters in cyclic group of order 2n+1.

A006205.name: Number of inequivalent strong starters in cyclic group of order 2n+1.

A006206.name: Number of aperiodic binary necklaces of length n with no subsequence 00, excluding the necklace "0".
formula: Coefficients of power series of natural logarithm of the infinite product Product_{n>=1} (1 - x^n - x^(2*n))^(-mu(n)/n), where mu(n) is the Moebius function. This is related to Fibonacci sequence since 1/(1 - x^n - x^(2*n)) expands to a power series whose terms are Fibonacci numbers.
a(n) = (1/n) * Sum_{d|n} mu(n/d) * (Fibonacci(d-1) + Fibonacci(d+1)) = (1/n) * Sum_{d|n} mu(n/d) * Lucas(d). Hence Lucas(n) = Sum_{d|n} d*a(d).

A006212.name: Number of down-up permutations of n+3 starting with n+1.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..1+floor((n+1)/2)} (-1)^i * binomial(n, 2*i+1) * E[n+1-2i], where E[j] = A000111(j) = j!*[x^j](sec(x) + tan(x)) are the up/down or Euler numbers.
a(n) = T(n+2, n), where T is the triangle in A008282. (End)
a(n) = E[n+2] - E[n] where E[n] = A000111(n). - _Gerald McGarvey_, Oct 09 2006
E.g.f.: (sec(x) + tan(x))^2/cos(x) - (sec(x) + tan(x)). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 29 2015
a(n) ~ n! * 2^(n+4) * n^2 / Pi^(n+3). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, May 07 2020

A006213.name: Number of down-up permutations of n+4 starting with n+1.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..1+floor((n+1)/2)} (-1)^i * binomial(n, 2*i+1) * E[n+2-2i], where E[j] = A000111(j) = j!*[x^j]((sec(x) + tan(x)) are the up/down or Euler numbers.
a(n) = T(n+3, n), where T is the triangle in A008282. (End)

A006214.name: Number of down-up permutations of n+5 starting with n+1.
formula: a(n) = sum((-1)^i*binomial(n, 2i+1)*E[n+3-2i], i=0..floor((n-1)/2)), where E[j]=A000111(j)=j!*[x^j]((sec(x)+tan(x)) are the up/down or Euler numbers. a(n)=T(n+4, n), where T is the triangle in A008282. - _Emeric Deutsch_, May 15 2004

A006215.name: Number of down-up permutations of n+6 starting with n+1.
formula: a(n) = Sum_{i=0..floor((n-1)/2)} (-1)^i * binomial(n, 2*i+1) * E[n + 4 - 2*i], where E[j] = A000111(j) = j! * [x^j] (sec(x) + tan(x)) are the up/down or Euler numbers.
a(n) = T(n+5, n), where T is the triangle in A008282. (End)

A006216.name: Number of down-up permutations of n+4 starting with 4.
formula: a(n) = 3*E(n+2) - E(n), where E(j) = A000111(j) = j!*[x^j](sec(x) + tan(x)) are the up/down or Euler numbers. - _Emeric Deutsch_, May 15 2004
E.g.f.: 6/(cos(x)*(1 - sin(x))) - tan(x) - 4*sec(x). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jun 04 2015

A006217.name: Number of down-up permutations of n+5 starting with 5.
formula: a(0) = 5 and a(n) = 4*E(n+3) - 4*E(n+1) for n >= 1, where E(j) = A000111(j) = j!*[x^j](sec(x) + tan(x)) are the up/down or Euler numbers. - _Emeric Deutsch_, May 15 2004

A006218.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=1..n} floor(n/k); also Sum_{k=1..n} d(k), where d = number of divisors (A000005); also number of solutions to x*y = z with 1 <= x,y,z <= n.
formula: a(n) = n * ( log(n) + 2*gamma - 1 ) + O(sqrt(n)), where gamma is the Euler-Mascheroni number ~ 0.57721... (see A001620), Dirichlet, 1849. Again, a(n) = n * ( log(n) + 2*gamma - 1 ) + O(log(n)*n^(1/3)). The determination of the precise size of the error term is an unsolved problem (the so-called Dirichlet divisor problem) - see references, especially Huxley (2003).
The bounds from Chandrasekharan lead to the explicit bounds n log(n) + (2 gamma - 1) n - 4 sqrt(n) - 1 <= a(n) <= n log(n) + (2 gamma - 1) n + 4 sqrt(n). - _David Applegate_, Oct 14 2008
For n > 0: A027750(a(n-1) + k) = k-divisor of n, = k <= A000005(n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 10 2006
D(n) = Sum_{m >= 2, r >= 1} (r/m^(r+1)) * Sum_{j = 1..m - 1} * Sum_{k = 0 .. m^(r+1) - 1} exp{ 2*k*pi i(p^n + (m - j)m^r) / m^(r+1) } where p is some fixed prime number. - _A. Neves_, Oct 04 2010

Let E(n) = a(n) - n(log n + 2 gamma - 1). Then Berkane-Bordellès-Ramaré show that |E(n)| <= 0.961 sqrt(n), |E(n)| <= 0.397 sqrt(n) for n > 5559, and |E(n)| <= 0.764 n^(1/3) log n for x > 9994. - _Charles R Greathouse IV_, Jul 02 2012
a(n) = Sum_{k = 1..floor(sqrt(n))} A005408(floor((n/k) - (k-1))). - _Gregory R. Bryant_, Apr 20 2013
Dirichlet g.f. for s > 2: Sum_{n>=1} a(n)/n^s = Sum_{k>=1} (Zeta(s-1) - Sum_{n=1..k-1} (HurwitzZeta(s,n/k)*n/k^s))/k. - _Mats Granvik_, Sep 24 2017

A006221.name: From Apery continued fraction for zeta(3): zeta(3)=6/(5-1^6/(117-2^6/(535-3^6/(1463...))).
formula: Can be extended to negative indices by: a(n) = -a(-1-n).

A006223.name: Number of binary rooted trees of height n requiring 3 registers.

A006224.name: Rabbytes: group eight successive Fibonacci numbers in binary and translate to decimal.

A006225.name: Rabbytes: group eight successive Fibonacci numbers in reversed binary and translate to decimal.

A006226.name: Number of abstract n-dimensional crystallographic point groups.

A006227.name: Number of n-dimensional space groups (including enantiomorphs).

A006228.name: Expansion of exp(arcsin(x)).
formula: i even: a_i = Product_{j=1..i/2-1} 1 + 4j^2, i odd: a_i = Product_{j=1..(i-1)/2} 2 + 4j(j-1). - Cris Moore (moore(AT)santafe.edu), Jan 31 2001
a(0)=1, a(1)=1, a(n) = (1+(n-2)^2)*a(n-2) for n >= 2. _Jaume Oliver Lafont_, Oct 24 2009

a(n) = (n-1)!*sum((if n=m then 1 else if oddp(n-m) then 0 else sum((-1)^k*(sum(C(k,j)*2^(1-j)*sum((-1)^((n-m)/2-i)*C(j,i)*(j-2*i)^(n-m+j)/(n-m+j)!, i=0..floor(j/2))*(-1)^(k-j), j=1..k))*C(k+n-1,n-1), k=1..n-m))/(m-1)!, m=1..n), n>0. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Sep 12 2010
E.g.f.: exp(arcsin(x))=1+2z/(H(0)-z); H(k)=4k+2+z^2*(4k^2+8k+5)/H(k+1), where z=x/((1-x^2)^1/2); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Nov 20 2011
a(n) = 2^(n-2) * (exp(Pi/2)-(-1)^n*exp(-Pi/2)) * GAMMA((n-I)/2) * GAMMA((n+I)/2) / Pi. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Nov 06 2014

A006229.name: Expansion of exp( tan x ).
formula: a(n) = sum(if oddp(n+k) then 0 else (-1)^((n+k)/2)*sum(j!/k!*stirling2(n,j)*2^(n-j)*(-1)^(n+j-k)*binomial(j-1,k-1),j,k,n),k,1,n), n>0. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Aug 05 2010
E.g.f.: 1 + tan(x)/T(0), where T(k) = 4*k+1 - tan(x)/(2 + tan(x)/(4*k+3 - tan(x)/(2 + tan(x)/T(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 03 2013
a(n) = sum(i=0..(n-1)/2, binomial(n-1,2*i)*z(i)*a(n-2*i-1)), a(0)=1, where z(n) is tangent (or "zag") numbers (A000182). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Mar 04 2015

A006230.name: Bitriangular permutations.
formula: a(n) = 12*S(n-2) + 1, with S(n)=A000392(n) the Stirling numbers of second kind, 3rd column. - _Ralf Stephan_, Jul 07 2003

A006231.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=2..n} n(n-1)...(n-k+1)/k.
formula: G.f.: (Q(0) - 1)/(1-x)^2, where Q(k)= 1 + (2*k + 1)*x/( 1 - x - 2*x*(1-x)*(k+1)/(2*x*(k+1) + (1-x)/Q(k+1))); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 09 2013

A006232.name: Numerators of Cauchy numbers of first type.
formula: Numerator of integral of x(x-1)...(x-n+1) from 0 to 1.
E.g.f.: x/log(1+x). (Note: the numerator of the coefficient of x^n/n! is a(n) - _Michael Somos_, Jul 12 2014)
Numerator of Sum_{k=0..n} A048994(n,k)/(k+1). - _Peter Luschny_, Apr 28 2009
Sum_{k=1..n} 1/k = C + log(n) + 1/(2n) + Sum_{k=2..inf} |a(n)|/A075178(n-1) * 1/(n*(n+1)*...*(n+k-1)) (section 0.131 in Gradshteyn and Ryzhik tables). - _Ralf Stephan_, Jul 12 2014
a(n) = numerator(f(n) * n!), where f(0) = 1, f(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} (-1)^(n-k+1) * f(k) / (n-k+1). - _Daniel Suteu_, Feb 23 2018
Sum_{k = 1..n} (1/k) = A001620 + log(n) + 1/(2n) - Sum_{k >= 2} abs((a(k)/A006233(k)/k/(Product_{j = 0..k-1} (n-j)))), (see I. S. Gradsteyn, I. M. Ryzhik). - _A.H.M. Smeets_, Nov 14 2018

A006233.name: Denominators of Cauchy numbers of first type.
formula: Denominator of integral of x(x-1)...(x-n+1) from 0 to 1.
Denominator of Sum_{k=0..n} A048994(n,k)/(k+1). [_Peter Luschny_, Apr 28 2009]
a(n) = denominator(f(n) * n!), where f(0) = 1, f(n) = Sum_{k=0..n-1} (-1)^(n-k+1) * f(k) / (n-k+1). - _Daniel Suteu_, Feb 23 2018
Sum_{k = 1..n} (1/k) = A001620 + log(n) + 1/(2*n) - Sum_{k >= 2} abs((A006232(k)/a(k)/k/(Product_{j = 0..k-1} (n-j)))), (see I. S. Gradsteyn, I. M. Ryzhik). - _A.H.M. Smeets_, Nov 14 2018

A006235.name: Complexity of doubled cycle (regarding case n = 2 as a multigraph).
formula: a(n) = (1/2)*n*(-2 + (2 - sqrt(3))^n + (2 + Sqrt(3))^n) (Kreweras). - _Eric W. Weisstein_, Jul 15 2011
a(n) = (n/2)*A129743(n). - Woong Kook and Seung Kyoon Shin (andrewk(AT)math.uri.edu), Jan 13 2009

A006237.name: Complexity of tensor sum of n graphs; or spanning trees on n-cube.

A006238.name: Complexity of (or spanning trees in) a 3 X n grid.
formula: a(n) = ( T(n,alpha) - T(n,beta) )/(alpha - beta), where alpha = (15 + sqrt(105))/4 and beta = (15 - sqrt(105))/4 and T(n,x) denotes the Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind.
a(n) = the bottom left entry of the 2X2 matrix T(n, M), where M is the 2X2 matrix [0, -15/2; 1, 15/2].
See the remarks in A100047 for the general connection between Chebyshev polynomials of the first kind and 4th-order linear divisibility sequences. (End)

A006239.name: Row 3 of array in A212801.
formula: Empirical closed form: a(n) = (2^n*(1+7^n) -(5-i*sqrt(3))^n -(5+i*sqrt(3))^n) / (3*2^n), where i=sqrt(-1). - _Bruno Berselli_, May 31 2012

A006240.name: Row 4 of array in A212801.
formula: Empirical closed form: a(n) = (15^n+3^n-5^n-1+(2+i)^n+(2-i)^n -(6+3*i)^n -(6-3*i)^n)/4, where i=sqrt(-1). - _Bruno Berselli_, May 31 2012

A006241.name: Number of minimal plane trees with n terminal nodes.
formula: a(1)=a(2)=a(3)=a(5)=a(7)=1, a(4)=2, a(6)=3, a(n) = Sum_{1 != d | n} a(n / d)^d [From Lew]. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Feb 07 2017 [typo corrected by _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 24 2019]

A006242.name: Extracting a square root.
formula: a(1) = 10, a(n) = a(n-1)^3 - 3*a(n-1) [From Escott]. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Feb 08 2017

A006244.name: Hexagonal numbers (A000384) which are also centered hexagonal numbers (A003215).
formula: We must solve 2*r^2-r=3*p^2-3*p+1, which gives X^2=6*Y^2+3 with X=4*r-1 and Y=2*p-1. We obtain at the same time the following sequences:
X is given by 3, 27, 267, ... sequence for which a(n+2)=10*a(n+1)-a(n) and a(n+1)=5*a(n)+2*(6a(n)^2-18)^0.5
Y is given by 1, 11, 109, ... sequence for which a(n+2)=10*a(n+1)-a(n) and a(n+1)=5*a(n)+2*(6a(n)^2+3)^0.5
p is given by 1, 6, 55, 540, ... sequence for which a(n+2)=10*a(n+1)-a(n)-4 and a(n+1)=5*a(n)-2+(24*a(n)^2-24*a(n)+9)^0.5
r is given by 1, 7, 67, 661, ... sequence for which a(n+2)=10*a(n+1)-a(n)-2 and a(n+1)=5*a(n)-1+(24*a(n)^2-12*a(n)-3)^0.5
Define x(n) + y(n)*sqrt(24) = (6+sqrt(24))*(5+sqrt(24))^n, s(n) = (y(n)+1)/2; then a(n) = (1/2)*(2+6*(s(n)^2-s(n))). - _Steven Schlicker_, Apr 24 2007

A006245.name: Number of primitive sorting networks on n elements; also number of rhombic tilings of 2n-gon.
formula: Felsner and Valtr show that 0.1887 <= log_2(a(n))/n^2 <= 0.6571 for sufficiently large n. - _Jeremy Tan_, Nov 20 2017

A006246.name: Number of primitive sorting networks on n elements.

A006247.name: Number of simple pseudoline arrangements with a marked cell. Number of Euclidean pseudo-order types: nondegenerate abstract order types of configurations of n points in the plane.
formula: Asymptotics: a(n) = 2^(Theta(n^2)). This is Bachmann-Landau notation, that is, there are constants n_0, c, and d, such that for every n >= n_0 the inequality 2^{c n^2} <= a(n) <= 2^{d n^2} is satisfied. For more information see e.g. the Handbook of Discrete and Computational Geometry. - _Manfred Scheucher_, Sep 12 2019

A006248.name: Number of primitive sorting networks on n elements. Number of projective pseudo order types: simple arrangements of pseudo-lines.
formula: Asymptotics: a(n) = 2^(Theta(n^2)). This is Bachmann-Landau notation, that is, there are constants n_0, c, and d, such that for every n >= n_0 the inequality 2^{c n^2} <= a(n) <= 2^{d n^2} is satisfied. For more information see e.g. the Handbook of Discrete and Computational Geometry. - _Manfred Scheucher_, Sep 12 2019

A006249.name: Number of hypertournaments on n elements under preisomorphism.

A006250.name: Number of hypertournaments on n elements under signed bijection.

A006251.name: Number of n-element posets which are unions of 2 chains.

A006252.name: Expansion of e.g.f. 1/(1 - log(1+x)).
formula: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} k!*stirling1(n, k). - _Vladeta Jovovic_, Sep 08 2002
a(n) = D^n(1/(1-x)) evaluated at x = 0, where D is the operator exp(-x)*d/dx. Row sums of A048594. Cf. A007840. - _Peter Bala_, Nov 25 2011
a(n)/n! ~ -(-1)^n / (n * (log(n))^2) * (1 - 2*(1 + gamma)/log(n)), where gamma is the Euler-Mascheroni constant A001620. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jul 01 2018

A006253.name: Number of perfect matchings (or domino tilings) in C_4 X P_n.
formula: G.f.: (1-x)/((1+x)*(1-4*x+x^2)) = (1-x)/(1-3*x-3*x^2+x^3). - _Simon Plouffe_ in his 1992 dissertation; typo corrected by _Vincenzo Librandi_, Oct 15 2012
For n >= 4, a(n) = 3a(n-1) + 3a(n-2) - a(n-3). - Avi Peretz (njk(AT)netvision.net.il), Mar 30 2001
For n >= 3, a(n) = 4a(n-1) - a(n-2) + 2*(-1)^n. - Ahmed Fares (ahmedfares(AT)my-deja.com), Apr 14 2001

From Dan Fux (dan.fux(AT)OpenGaia.com or danfux(AT)OpenGaia.com), Apr 11 2001: The values are a(1) = 2 * 1^2, a(2) = 3^2, a(3) = 2 * 4^2, a(4) = 11^2, a(5) = 2 * 15^2, ... and in general for odd n a(n) is twice a square, for even n a(n) is a square. If we define b(n) by b(n) = sqrt(a(n)) for even n, b(n) = sqrt(a(n)/2) for odd n then apart from the first 2 elements b(n) is A002530(n+1).
a(n)= |U(n,i/sqrt(2))|^2 where U(n,x) denotes the Chebyshev polynomial of the second kind.
a(n-1) = the bottom left entry of the 2 X 2 matrix T(n, M), where M is the 2 X 2 matrix [0, 2; 1, 1] and T(n,x) denotes the Chebyshev polynomial of the first kind.
See the remarks in A100047 for the general connection between Chebyshev polynomials of the first kind and 4th order linear divisibility sequences. (End)

A006254.name: Numbers k such that 2k-1 is prime.

A006255.name: R. L. Graham's sequence: a(n) = smallest m for which there is a sequence n = b_1 < b_2 < ... < b_t = m such that b_1*b_2*...*b_t is a perfect square.
formula: If n is a square we can take t=1 and a(n)=n.

A006256.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} binomial(3k,k)*binomial(3n-3k,n-k).
formula: a(n) = (3/4)*(27/4)^n*(1+c/sqrt(n)+o(n^(-1/2))) where c = (2/3)*sqrt(1/(3*Pi)) = 0.217156671956853298... More generally, a(n, m) = sum(k=0, n, C(m*k,k) *C(m*(n-k),n-k)) is asymptotic to (1/2)*m/(m-1)*(m^m/(m-1)^(m-1))^n. See A000302, A078995 for cases m=2 and 4. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Jan 26 2003, extended by _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Nov 06 2012
G.f.: 1/(1-3*z*g^2)^2, where g=g(z) is given by g=1+z*g^3, g(0)=1, i.e. (in Maple command) g := 2*sin(arcsin(3*sqrt(3*z)/2)/3)/sqrt(3*z). - _Emeric Deutsch_, May 22 2003
From _Rui Duarte_ and António Guedes de Oliveira, Feb 17 2013: (Start)
a(n) = sum(k=0, n, C(3*k+l,k)*C(3*(n-k)-l,n-k)) for every real number l.
From _Akalu Tefera_, Sean Meehan, Michael Weselcouch, and Aklilu Zeleke, May 11 2013: (Start)

A006257.name: Josephus problem: a(2*n) = 2*a(n)-1, a(2*n+1) = 2*a(n)+1.
formula: To get a(n), write n in binary, rotate left 1 place.
a(n) = 2*A053645(n) + 1 = 2(n-msb(n))+1. - _Marc LeBrun_, Jul 11 2001. Here "msb" = "most significant bit", A053644.
a(n) = number of positive integers k < n such that n XOR k < n. a(n) = n - A035327(n). - _Paul D. Hanna_, Jan 21 2006
a(n) = n for n = 2^k - 1. - _Zak Seidov_, Dec 14 2006
a(n) = 2*(n - 2^floor(log_2(n))) + 1 (see comment above). - _Gregory Pat Scandalis_, Oct 15 2013
a(n) = 0 if n = 0 and a(n) = 2*a(floor(n/2)) - (-1)^(n mod 2) if n > 0. - _Marek A. Suchenek_, Mar 31 2016
G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = 2*A(x^2)*(1 + x) + x/(1 + x). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Aug 31 2019

A006261.name: a(n) = Sum_{k=0..5} C(n,k).
formula: a(n) = binomial(n+1, 5) + binomial(n+1, 3) + binomial(n+1, 1). - _Len Smiley_, Oct 20 2001

A006265.name: Number of shapes of height-balanced AVL trees with n nodes.
formula: G.f.: A(x) = B(x,0) where B(x,y) satisfies B(x,y) = x + B(x^2+2xy,x).

A006266.name: A continued cotangent.
formula: a(n+1) = a(n)^3 + 3*a(n) with a(1)=2.  a(n+1)=round((1+sqrt(2))^(3^n)). -  _Artur Jasinski_, Sep 24 2008, Corrected by _M. F. Hasler_, Oct 06 2014

A006267.name: Continued cotangent for the golden ratio.
formula: (1+sqrt(5))/2 = cot(Sum_{n>=0} (-1)^n*acot(a(n))); let b(0) = (1+sqrt(5))/2, b(n) = (b(n-1)*floor(b(n-1))+1)/(b(n-1)-floor(b(n-1)) then a(n) = floor(b(n)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Apr 10 2003
a(n) = Round(c^(3^n)) where c = GoldenRatio = 1.6180339887498948482... = (sqrt(5)+1)/2. - _Artur Jasinski_, Sep 22 2008
Recurrence a(n+1) = a(n)^3 + 3*a(n), a(0)=4. - _Artur Jasinski_, Sep 24 2008
a(n+1) = Product_{k = 0..n} A002813(k). Thus a(n) divides a(n+1). - _Peter Bala_, Nov 22 2012

A006270.name: Denominators of a continued fraction for (1 + sqrt(5))/2.

A006271.name: Numerators of a continued fraction for 1 + sqrt(2).

A006272.name: Denominators of a continued fraction for 1 + sqrt(2).

A006273.name: Numerators of a continued fraction for (3+sqrt(13))/2.

A006274.name: Denominators of a continued fraction for (3+sqrt(13))/2.

A006275.name: Pierce expansion of sqrt(2) - 1.
formula: Let u(0)=1+sqrt(2) and u(n+1)=u(n)/frac(u(n)) where frac(x) is the fractional part of x, then a(n)=floor(u(n)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 09 2004

A006276.name: Pierce expansion of (3 - sqrt(5))/2.
formula: a(n) = 2*F(2*3^floor(n/2)+1)-F(2*3^floor(n/2))-(-1)^n where F(k) denotes the k-th Fibonacci number A000045(k)
Let u(0)=(1+sqrt(5))/2 and u(n+1)=u(n)/frac(u(n)) where frac(x) is the fractional part of x, then a(n)=floor(u(n)). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 09 2004

A006277.name: a(n) = (a(n-1) + 1)*a(n-2).
formula: a(n) = floor(A243967^(phi^n) * A243968^((1-phi)^n)), where phi is the golden ratio (1+sqrt(5))/2. - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Jan 19 2015

A006278.name: a(n) is the product of the first n primes congruent to 1 (mod 4).
formula: a(n) = Product_{i=1..n} A002144(i). - _Alois P. Heinz_, Mar 01 2021

A006279.name: Denominators of convergents to Cahen's constant: a(n+2) = a(n)^2*a(n+1) + a(n).

A006280.name: Partial quotients in continued fraction expansion of Cahen's constant.

A006281.name: Partial quotients in continued fraction expansion of 2C-1, where C is Cahen's constant.

A006282.name: Sorting numbers: number of comparisons in Batcher's parallel sort.
formula: a(1)=0, a(n)=a(ceiling(n/2))+a([ n/2 ])+C(ceiling(n/2), [ n/2 ]), n>1, where the C function is defined in Knuth by C[m,n] = m*n if m*n <=1 and C[m,n] = C[Ceiling[m/2],Ceiling[n/2]] + C[Floor[m/2],Floor[n/2]] + Floor[(m+n-1)/2]] otherwise.

A006284.name: Pierce expansion for Euler's constant.
formula: If u(0) = exp(1/m), where m is an integer >=1, and u(n+1) = u(n)/frac(u(n)) then floor(u(n)) = m*n. Let u(0)=1/gamma and u(n+1) = u(n)/frac(u(n)) where frac(x) is the fractional part of x, then a(n) = floor(u(n)) - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 09 2004

A006285.name: Odd numbers not of form p + 2^k (de Polignac numbers).
formula: Conjecture: a(n) ~ n*exp(2/log(2)) = n*17.91... - _Thomas Ordowski_, Feb 02 2021

A006287.name: Sum of squares of digits of ternary representation of n.

A006288.name: Loxton-van der Poorten sequence: base-4 representation contains only -1, 0, +1.
formula: Recurrence: a(3n) = 4a(n), a(3n-1) = 4a(n)-1, a(3n+1) = 4a(n)+1, starting 0,1. - _Ralf Stephan_, Jan 19 2014

A006289.name: Number of series-reduced 2-connected graphs with n nodes.

A006290.name: Number of 3-connected graphs with n nodes.

A006294.name: Number of rooted planar maps with n edges.

A006295.name: Number of genus 1 rooted maps with 2 faces with n vertices

A006296.name: Number of genus 1 rooted maps with 3 faces with n vertices.

A006297.name: Number of rooted genus-1 maps with n edges.

A006298.name: Number of genus 2 rooted maps with 1 face with n vertices.
formula: G.f.: 21*x^4*(1+x)/sqrt((1-4*x)^11). a(n) = 21 * (A020922(n-4) + A020922(n-3)). - _Ralf Stephan_, Mar 13 2004 (g.f. corrected by _Joerg Arndt_, Apr 07 2013)

A006299.name: Number of rooted genus-2 maps with n edges.

A006300.name: Number of rooted maps with n edges on torus.
formula: G.f.: (R-1)^2/(12*R^2*(R+2)) where R=sqrt(1-12*x); a(n) is asymptotic to 12^n/24. - Pab Ter (pabrlos2(AT)yahoo.com), Nov 07 2005

A006301.name: Number of rooted genus-2 maps with n edges.

A006302.name: Related to enumeration of rooted maps.

A006303.name: Related to enumeration of rooted maps.

A006304.name: Coefficients of the '2nd order' mock theta function A(q).

A006305.name: Taylor series related to one in Ramanujan's Lost Notebook.

A006306.name: Coefficients of the '2nd order' mock theta function mu(q).

A006307.name: Number of ways writing 2^n as unordered sums of 2 primes.

A006308.name: Coefficients of period polynomials.
formula: For an odd prime p, let g be a primitive root of p^2, q=g^p, and zeta=exp(2*pi*i/p^2).  Define h(p,k) = Sum_{j=0..p-2} zeta^((q+k*p)*q^j) and a polynomial f(p,x) = Product_{k=0..p-1} (x-h(p,k)). Finally, a(n) = -[x^(p-2)] f(p,x) where p = A000040(n) is the n-th prime. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Mar 07 2017

A006309.name: Coefficients of period polynomials.
formula: a(n) = [x^(p-3)] f(p,x) where p = A000040(n) and f(p,x) is defined in A006308. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Mar 07 2017

A006310.name: a(n) = norm of Heilbronn sum NH_{p}, with p = prime(n).

A006311.name: Coefficients of period polynomials.
formula: a(n) = [x^1] f(p,x) where p = A000040(n) and f(p,x) is defined in A006308. - _Sean A. Irvine_, Mar 08 2017

A006313.name: Numbers n such that n^16 + 1 is prime.

A006314.name: Numbers n such that n^8 + 1 is prime.

A006315.name: Numbers n such that n^32 + 1 is prime.

A006316.name: Numbers n such that n^64 + 1 is prime.

A006317.name: Maximum number of chess queens of 3 colors on an n X n board such that no queen attacks or protects another queen of its color.

A006318.name: Large Schröder numbers (or large Schroeder numbers, or big Schroeder numbers).
formula: For n > 0, a(n) = (1/n)*Sum_{k = 0..n} 2^k*C(n, k)*C(n, k-1). - _Benoit Cloitre_, May 10 2003
The g.f. satisfies (1 - x)*A(x) - x*A(x)^2 = 1. - _Ralf Stephan_, Jun 30 2003
For the asymptotic behavior, see A001003 (remembering that A006318 = 2*A001003). - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Apr 10 2011
Row sums of A088617 and A060693.
With offset 1 : a(1) = 1, a(n) = a(n-1) + Sum_{i = 1..n-1} a(i)*a(n-i). - _Benoit Cloitre_, Mar 16 2004
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} A000108(k)*binomial(n+k, n-k). - _Benoit Cloitre_, May 09 2004
a(n) = Sum_{k = 0..n} A011117(n, k). - _Philippe Deléham_, Jul 10 2004

a(n) = (CentralDelannoy(n+1) - 3 * CentralDelannoy(n))/(2*n) = (-CentralDelannoy(n+1) + 6 * CentralDelannoy(n) - CentralDelannoy(n-1))/2 for n >= 1, where CentralDelannoy is A001850. - _David Callan_, Aug 16 2006

Define the general Delannoy numbers d(i, j) as in A001850. Then a(k) = d(2*k, k) - d(2*k, k-1) and a(0) = 1, Sum_{j=0..n} ((-1)^j * (d(n, j) + d(n-1, j-1)) * a(n-j)) = 0. - _Peter E John_, Oct 19 2006

Given an integer t >= 1 and initial values u = [a_0, a_1, ..., a_{t-1}], we may define an infinite sequence Phi(u) by setting a_n = a_{n-1} + a_0*a_{n-1} + a_1*a_{n-2} + ... + a_{n-2}*a_1 for n >= t. For example, Phi([1]) is the Catalan numbers A000108. The present sequence is (essentially) Phi([2]). - _Gary W. Adamson_, Oct 27 2008
G.f.: 1/(1 - x - x/(1 - x - x/(1 - x - x/(1 - x - x/(1 - x - x/(1 - ... (continued fraction). - _Paul Barry_, Jan 29 2009
Logarithmic derivative yields A002003. - _Paul D. Hanna_, Oct 25 2010
a(n) = the upper left term in M^(n+1), M = the production matrix:
a(n) is the sum of top row terms in Q^n, Q = an infinite square production matrix as follows:
With F(x) = (1 - 3*x - sqrt(1 - 6*x + x^2))/(2*x) an o.g.f. (nulling the n = 0 term) for A006318, G(x) = x/(2 + 3*x + x^2) is the compositional inverse.
a(n) = (1/n!)*[(H(x)*d/dx)^n] x evaluated at x = 0, i.e.,
F(x) = exp[x*H(u)*d/du] u, evaluated at u = 0. Also, dF(x)/dx = H(F(x)). (End)

a(n-1) = number of ordered complete binary trees with n leaves having k internal vertices colored black, the remaining n - 1 - k internal vertices colored white, and such that each vertex and its rightmost child have different colors ([Drake, Example 1.6.7]). For a refinement of this sequence see A175124. - _Peter Bala_, Sep 29 2011
G.f.: A(x) = (1 - x - sqrt(1 - 6*x + x^2))/(2*x)= (1 - G(0))/x; G(k) = 1 + x - 2*x/G(k+1); (continued fraction, 1-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 04 2012
G.f.: A(x) = (1 - x - sqrt(1 - 6*x + x^2))/(2*x) = (G(0) - 1)/x; G(k)= 1 - x/(1 - 2/G(k+1)); (continued fraction, 2-step). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jan 04 2012
a(n+1) = a(n) + sum (a(k)*(n-k): k = 0..n). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Nov 13 2012
G.f.: 1/Q(0) where Q(k) =  1 + k*(1 - x) - x - x*(k+1)*(k+2)/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Mar 14 2013
G.f.: 1/x - 1 - U(0)/x, where U(k)= 1 - x - x/U(k+1) ; (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 16 2013
G.f.: (2 - 2*x - G(0))/(4*x), where G(k)= 1 + 1/( 1 - x*(6 - x)*(2*k - 1)/(x*(6 - x)*(2*k - 1) + 2*(k + 1)/G(k+1) )); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Jul 16 2013
a(n) = 1/(n + 1) (Sum_{j=0..n} C(n+j, j)*C(n+j+1, j+1)*(Sum_{k=0..n-j} (-1)^k*C(n+j+k, k))). - _Graham H. Hawkes_, Feb 15 2015
a(n) = sqrt(2) * LegendreP(n, -1, 3) where LegendreP is the associated Legendre function of the first kind (in Maple's notation). - _Robert Israel_, Mar 23 2015
G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = Sum_{j>=0} x^j * Sum_{k=0..j} binomial(j,k)*A(x)^k. - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 11 2019

A006319.name: Royal paths in a lattice (convolution of A006318).
formula: All listed terms satisfy the recurrence a(1) = 1 and, for n > 1, a(n) = 4*a(n-1) + Sum_{k=2..n-2} a(k)*a(n-k-1). - _John W. Layman_, Feb 23 2001
G.f.: 1/(1-z/(1-z/(1-z/(...)))) where z = x/(1-x)^2 (continued fraction); more generally g.f. C(x/(1-x)^2) where C(x) is the g.f. for the Catalan numbers (A000108). - _Joerg Arndt_, Mar 18 2011
a(n) is the sum of top row terms in M^(n-1), M = an infinite square production matrix as follows:
D-finite with recurrence: (n+1)*a(n) + (-7*n+4)*a(n-1) + (7*n-17)*a(n-2) + (-n+4)*a(n-3) = 0. - _R. J. Mathar_, Oct 16 2013
a(n) = Sum_{k=0..n} (2/(k+2))*binomial(n+k,k+1)*binomial(n-1,k) for n >= 1. - _David Callan_, Jul 21 2017
G.f. A(x) satisfies: A(x) = 1/(1 - Sum_{k>=1} k*x^k*A(x)). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Apr 10 2018
O.g.f. A(x) = (1 - x)*( (1 - x) - sqrt(1 - 6*x + x^2) )/(2*x) = (1 - x)*S(x) = 1 + x*S(x)^2, where S(x) is the o.g.f. for the large Schröder numbers A006318. (End)
a(n) = 0^n + n*hypergeom([1 - n, n + 1], [3], -1). - _Peter Luschny_, Jan 31 2020

A006320.name: Royal paths in a lattice.
formula: 3-fold convolution of the large Schroeder numbers (A006318). G.f.=R^3, where R=[1-z-sqrt(1-6z+z^2)]/(2z) is the g.f. of A006318. - _Emeric Deutsch_, Mar 15 2004
a(n) = (3/n)*sum(binomial(n, j)*binomial(n+2+j, n-1), j=0..n) (n>0). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Aug 19 2004
a(n) ~ 3 * (1 + sqrt(2))^(2*n+3) / (2^(3/4) * sqrt(Pi) * n^(3/2)). - _Vaclav Kotesovec_, Oct 05 2012, simplified Dec 24 2017

A006321.name: Royal paths in a lattice.
formula: a(n) = (4/n)*sum(binomial(n, j)*binomial(n+3+j, n-1), j=0..n) (n>0). - _Emeric Deutsch_, Aug 19 2004

A006322.name: 4-dimensional analog of centered polygonal numbers.
formula: a(n) = (((n+1)^5-n^5) - ((n+1)^3-n^3))/24. - Xavier Acloque, Jan 14 2003, corrected by _Eric Rowland_, Aug 15 2017
Partial sums of A004068. - Xavier Acloque, Jan 15 2003
a(n) = Sum_{i=1..n} Sum_{j=1..n} i * min(i,j). - _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Jan 30 2013

A006324.name: a(n) = n*(n + 1)*(2*n^2 + 2*n - 1)/6.
formula: a(n) = (Sum_{k=1..n} k^5) / (Sum_{k=1..n} k) = A000539(n) / A000217(n). - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Apr 12 2006
Recurrence relation 0 = Sum_{k=0..5} (-1)^k*binomial(5,k)*a(n-k). - _Johannes W. Meijer_, Jun 27 2009

A006325.name: 4-dimensional analog of centered polygonal numbers.
formula: The partial sums of the octahedral numbers: a(n+1) = Sum_{i=0..n} A005900(i). - _Jonathan Vos Post_, Mar 14 2006

a(n) = Sum_{i=1..n-1} Sum_{j=1..n-1} min(i,j)^2. - _Enrique Pérez Herrero_, Jan 15 2013 [Which is just rephrasing the partial sum formula with the Murthy formula in A005900. - _R. J. Mathar_, Jun 14 2014]

A006327.name: a(n) = Fibonacci(n) - 3. Number of total preorders.
formula: a(n) = F(4*n) mod F(n+1) = F(n) - (F(n+4)^2 - F(n)^2)/F(2*n+4). - _Gary Detlefs_, Apr 02 2012

A006330.name: Number of corners, or planar partitions of n with only one row and one column.
formula: Convolution product of A197870 and A000712. - _Michael Somos_, Feb 22 2015

A006331.name: a(n) = n*(n+1)*(2*n+1)/3.
formula: G.f.: 2*x*(1 + x)/(1 - x)^4. - _Simon Plouffe_ (in his 1992 dissertation)
a(n) = Sum_{i=0..n} T(i,n-i), array T as in A048147. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Dec 11 1999

From the formula for the sum of squares of positive integers 1^2 + 2^2 + 3^2 + ... + n^2 = n*(n+1)(2*n+1)/6, if we multiply both sides by 2 we get Sum_{k=0..n} 2*k^2 = n*(n+1)*(2*n+1)/3, which is an alternative formula for this sequence. - _Mike Warburton_, Sep 08 2007
a(n) = sum(a*b), where the summing is over all unordered partitions 2*n+1=a+b. - _Vladimir Shevelev_, May 11 2012

A006336.name: a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n - 1 - number of even terms so far).
formula: Comment from Paul D. Hanna, Jul 22 2007: It seems that A006336 can be generated by a rule using the golden ratio phi: a(n) = a(n-1) + a([n/Phi]) for n>1 with a(1)=1 where phi = (sqrt(5)+1)/2, I.e. the number of even terms up to position n-1 equals n-1 - [n/Phi] for n>1 where Phi = (sqrt(5)+1)/2. (This is true - see the Alekseyev link.)
a(n)=a(n-1)+a(A060143(n)) for n>1; subsequence of A134409; A134408 and A134409 give first and second differences; A001950(n)=Min(m:A134409(m)=a(n)). - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, Oct 24 2007

A006337.name: An "eta-sequence": floor( (n+1)*sqrt(2) ) - floor( n*sqrt(2) ).
formula: Let S(0) = 1; obtain S(k) from S(k-1) by applying 1 -> 12, 2 -> 112; sequence is S(0), S(1), S(2), ... - _Matthew Vandermast_, Mar 25 2003

A006338.name: An "eta-sequence": floor((n+1)*sqrt(2) + 1/2) - floor(n*sqrt(2) + 1/2).
formula: a(n) = floor((n+1)*sqrt(2) + 1/2) - floor(n*sqrt(2) + 1/2). - _G. C. Greubel_, Nov 18 2017

A006339.name: Least hypotenuse of n distinct Pythagorean triangles.

A006341.name: Octal palindromes which are also primes.

A006342.name: Coloring a circuit with 4 colors.
formula: Binomial transform of A002001 (with interpolated zeros). Partial sums of A054878. E.g.f.: exp(x)(3*cosh(2*x) + 1)/4; a(n) = 3*3^n/8 + 1/4 + 3(-1)^n/8 = Sum_{k=0..n} (3^k + 3(-1)^k)/4. - _Paul Barry_, Sep 03 2003

A006343.name: Arkons: number of elementary maps with n-1 nodes.
formula: O.g.f. A(x) equals 1/x * series reversion ( x/(1 + x^2*C(x) ), where C(x) = (1 - sqrt(1 - 4*x))/(2*x) is the o.g.f. for A000108.
A(x) is an algebraic function satisfying x^3*A^3(x) - (x - 1)*A^2(x) + (x - 2)*A(x) + 1 = 0. (End)

A006344.name: Number of rooted maps with n edges on Klein bottle.

A006345.name: Linus sequence: a(n) "breaks the pattern" by avoiding the longest doubled suffix.

A006346.name: The Sally sequence: the length of repetition avoided in A006345.

A006347.name: a(n) = (n+1) a(n-1) + (-1)^n.
formula: a(n) = n(a(n-1) + a(n-2)), n > 2. - _Gary Detlefs_, Apr 10 2010

A006348.name: a(n) = (n+2)*a(n-1) + (-1)^n.
formula: E.g.f. with offset 0: ((2 + 3*x + x^3)*exp(-x) - 2)/(1 - x)^4. From int(((9 + 8*x + 6*x^2 + x^4)*exp(-x) - 8)/(1 - x)^5, x) with input 0 for x = 0. - _Wolfdieter Lang_, May 03 2010

A006351.name: Number of series-parallel networks with n labeled edges. Also called yoke-chains by Cayley and MacMahon.
formula: Also exponential transform of A000311, define b by 1+sum b_n x^n / n! = exp ( 1 + sum a_n x^n /n!).
E.g.f.: A(x), B(x)=x*A(x) satisfies the differential equation B'(x)=(1+B(x))/(1-B(x)). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Jan 18 2011

The generating function A(x) satisfies the autonomous differential equation A'(x) = (1+A)/(1-A) with A(0) = 0. Hence the inverse function A^-1(x) = int {t = 0..x} (1-t)/(1+t) = 2*log(1+x)-x, which yields A(x) = -1-2*W(-1/2*exp((x-1)/2)), where W is the Lambert W function.

The expansion of A(x) can be found by inverting the above integral using the method of [Dominici, Theorem 4.1] to arrive at the result a(n) = D^(n-1)(1) evaluated at x = 0, where D denotes the operator g(x) -> d/dx((1+x)/(1-x)*g(x)). Compare with A032188.

Applying [Bergeron et al., Theorem 1] to the result x = int {t = 0..A(x)} 1/phi(t), where phi(t) = (1+t)/(1-t) = 1 + 2*t + 2*t^2 + 2*t^3 + ..., leads to the following combinatorial interpretation for the sequence: a(n) gives the number of plane increasing trees on n vertices where each vertex of outdegree k >=1 can be in one of 2 colors. An example is given below. (End)
G.f.: 1/S(0) where S(k) = 1 - x*(k+1) - x*(k+1)/S(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Dec 18 2011
E.g.f.: A(x) = exp(B(x))-1 where B(x) is the e.g.f. of A000311. - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, Sep 25 2012
G.f.: -1 + 2/Q(0), where Q(k)= 1 - k*x - x*(k+1)/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, May 01 2013
G.f.: Q(0)/(1-x), where Q(k) = 1 - x*(k+1)/( x*(k+1) - (1 -x*(k+1))*(1 -x*(k+2))/Q(k+1) ); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 10 2013
a(1) = 1; a(n) = a(n-1) + Sum_{k=1..n-1} binomial(n-1,k) * a(k) * a(n-k). - _Ilya Gutkovskiy_, Aug 28 2020

A006352.name: Coefficients in expansion of Eisenstein series E_2 (also called E_1 or G_2).
formula: G.f.: 1 + 24 *x*deriv(eta(x))/eta(x) where eta(x) = prod(n>=1, 1-x^n); (cf. A000203). - _Joerg Arndt_, Sep 28 2012
G.f.: q*Delta'/Delta where Delta is the generating function of Ramanujan's tau function (A000594). - _Seiichi Manyama_, Jul 15 2017

A006353.name: Expansion of (phi(-q^3) * psi(q))^3 / (phi(-q) * psi(q^3)) in powers of q where phi(), psi() are Ramanujan theta functions.
formula: Expansion of (b(q^2)^2 / b(q)) * (c(q)^2 / c(q^2)) / 3 in powers of q where b(), c() are cubic AGM theta functions.
Expansion of (eta(q^2) * eta(q^3))^7 / (eta(q) * eta(q^6))^5 in powers of q.
Euler transform of period 6 sequence [5, -2, -2, -2, 5, -4, ...]. - _Michael Somos_, Oct 11 2006
G.f. is a period 1 Fourier series which satisfies f(-1 / (6 t)) = 6 (t / i)^2 f(t) where q = exp(2 Pi i t). - _Michael Somos_, Sep 04 2013

G.f.: Sum_{n>=0} A005259(n)*t(q)^n where t(q) = (eta(q)*eta(q^6)/(eta(q^2)*eta(q^3))^12. - _Seiichi Manyama_, Jun 10 2017 [See the Kontsevich-Zagier paper, section 2.4., and t is given in A226235.] - _Wolfdieter Lang_, May 16 2018 ]

A006354.name: Expansion of a cusp form of weight 8 for Gamma_1(6).

A006355.name: Number of binary vectors of length n containing no singletons.
formula: a(n) = A119457(n-1,n-2) for n > 2. - _Reinhard Zumkeller_, May 20 2006
a(n) = 2*F(n-1) for n > 0, F(n)=A000045(n) and a(0)=1. - _Mircea Merca_, Jun 28 2012
G.f.: 1 - x + x*Q(0), where Q(k) = 1 + x^2 + (2*k+3)*x - x*(2*k+1 + x)/Q(k+1); (continued fraction). - _Sergei N. Gladkovskii_, Oct 05 2013
a(n) = (2^(-n)*((1-r)^n*(1+r) + (-1+r)*(1+r)^n)) / r for n > 0, where r=sqrt(5). - _Colin Barker_, Jan 28 2017
a(n) = a(n-1) + a(n-2) for n >= 3. - _Armend Shabani_, Nov 25 2020

A006356.name: a(n) = 2*a(n-1) + a(n-2) - a(n-3) for n >= 3, starting with a(0) = 1, a(1) = 3, and a(2) = 6.
formula: a(n-1) = Sum_{k = 1..n} Sum_{i = k..n} Sum_{j = 0..k} binomial(j, -3*k+2*j+i) * (-1)^(j-k) * binomial(k, j) * binomial(n+k-i-1, k-1). - _Vladimir Kruchinin_, May 05 2011

A006357.name: Number of distributive lattices; also number of paths with n turns when light is reflected from 4 glass plates.
formula: a(n) is asymptotic to z(4)*w(4)^n where w(4) = (1/2)/cos(4*Pi/9) and z(4) is the root 1 < x < 2 of P(4, X) = 1 + 27*X - 324*X^2 + 243*X^3. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Oct 16 2002
Binomial transform of A122167(unsigned): (1, 3, 3, 11, 10, 40, 33, 146, ...). - _Gary W. Adamson_, Nov 24 2007

A006358.name: Number of distributive lattices; also number of paths with n turns when light is reflected from 5 glass plates.
formula: a(n) is asymptotic to z(5)*w(5)^n where w(5) = (1/2)/cos(5*Pi/11) and z(5) is the root 1 < x < 2 of P(5, X) = -1 + 55*X + 847*X^2 - 5324*X^3 - 14641*X^4 + 14641*X^5. - _Benoit Cloitre_, Oct 16 2002

A006359.name: Number of distributive lattices; also number of paths with n turns when light is reflected from 6 glass plates.
formula: G.f.: -(z^4 + z^3 - 3z^2 - 2z + 1) / (-1 + 3z + 6z^2 - 4z^3 - 5z^4 + z^5 + z^6). - M. Goebel (manfredg(AT)ICSI.Berkeley.EDU) Jul 26 1997

a(n) is asymptotic to z(6)*w(6)^n where w(6) = (1/2)/cos(6*Pi/13) and z(6) is the root 1 < x < 2 of P(6, X) = -1 - 91*X + 2366*X^2 + 26364*X^3 - 142805*X^4 - 371293*X^5 + 371293*X^6 - _Benoit Cloitre_, Oct 16 2002

A006360.name: Antichains (or order ideals) in the poset 2*2*3*n or size of the distributive lattice J(2*2*3*n)

A006361.name: Antichains (or order ideals) in the poset 2*2*4*n or size of the distributive lattice J(2*2*4*n)

A006362.name: Antichains (or order ideals) in the poset 2*2*5*n or size of the distributive lattice J(2*2*5*n)

A006363.name: Number of antichains (or order ideals) in the poset B_4 X [n]; or size of the distributive lattice J(B_4 X [n]).

A006364.name: Numbers n with an even number of 1's in binary, ignoring last bit.
formula: Union of 2*A001969 and 2*A001969+1. With initial index 0: a(2n+1) = a(2n)+1, a(4n) = a(2n)+4n, a(4n+2) = -a(2n)+12n+6. - _Ralf Stephan_, Oct 17 2003

A006365.name: Number of binary tree partitions.
formula: G.f.: G(z) = lim G_m(z), m -> inf, where G_m(z) = (2z^m)^(-1)*{1- sqrt( 1 - 4z^m Sum z^k*G_k(z)^2, 0<=k<m)}.

Given the AGM-like recursion f(a0,b0,c0) = (a1,b1,c1) where a0^2=b0^2+2*a0*c0, a1^2=b1^2+2*a1*c1, a1=(a0+b0)/2, c1=c0*x with initial values a0=1, c0=2*x, then the common limit of a and b is 1/A(x). - _Michael Somos_, Sep 18 2006

A006366.name: Number of cyclically symmetric plane partitions in the n-cube; also number of 2n X 2n half-turn symmetric alternating sign matrices divided by number of n X n alternating sign matrices.

A006367.name: Number of binary vectors of length n+1 beginning with 0 and containing just 1 singleton.
formula: Convolution square of A212804. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 29 2014
a(n) = -(-1)^n * A004798(-1-n) for all n in Z. - _Michael Somos_, Nov 29 2014

A006368.name: The "amusical permutation" of the nonnegative numbers: a(2n)=3n, a(4n+1)=3n+1, a(4n-1)=3n-1.
formula: If n even, then a(n) = 3n/2; otherwise, a(n) = nearest integer to 3n/4.
a(n) = ((n+1) mod 2) * (3n/2) + (n mod 2) * round(3n/4). - _Wesley Ivan Hurt_, Nov 23 2013
